item.title: Iâm Moving so I can Blog with IPython Notebook
item.description:
To gain a deeper understanding of the GNU Radio software, I want to rebuild some skills & insights in digital signal processing. But before I take on this topic, I want to refresh my signals & systems skills I learned long ago while in college. I have chosen Mark Wickertâs book, Signals and Systems For Dummies, to do this.

Go ahead and laugh if you wish, but I got good reasons for choosing this book. I like its brevity, since I donât want to spend a great deal of time re-honing these old skills (I expect them to come back quickly), and its use of IPython will help me master a powerful tool that I foresee using within this blog; specifically the IPython Notebook. To begin learning IPython, Iâm currently reading Learning IPython for Interactive Computing and Data Visualization by Cyrille Rossant. So itâs currently âback to schoolâ for me on many levels.

So this brings me to the topic of this posting. Initially I considered moving my blog off of WordPress.com to a WordPress.org hosting site. This should allow me to post IPython Notebook pages. WordPress.com is very restrictive on what you can do with your blog, but the WordPress software, when self hosted via WordPress.org, can provide you a great deal of blogging freedom. I need to take advantage of some of the powerful WordPress Plugins and WordPress.com will not support any of them. Moving to a self-hosted WordPress blog doesnât appear to be very difficult. The biggest trick will be picking the right web hosting company that is strong WordPress supporter who will make it easily move my blog from WordPress.com to WordPress.org.

I then took a closer look at how others have successfully using IPython Notebook for blogging. I took a very close look at Carl Boettigerâs Online Lab Notebook. This introduced me to GitHub Pages and Jekyll. With these tools you can create an archived, static site that is hosted for free. I saw the synergy between these tools and how I work with my Linux box, electronics, and now IPython and its seemed like the way to go.

Jekyll is a simple, blog aware, static site generator. It takes a template directory (representing the raw form of a website), runs it through Textile or Markdown and Liquid converters, and spits out a complete, static website suitable for serving with Apache or your favorite web server. The site âLearning Jekyll By Example: Build a Jekyll Website, Start to Finishâ says it well:

  • Jekyll can be hosted on any web hosting service that serves static files.
  • Jekyll-powered websites are also extremely secure.
  • Jekyll is mainly targeted at tech-savvy bloggers.
  • But what Jekyll lacks in newbie-friendliness it makes up for in power and flexibility.
  • Jekyll allows you, the content author, to display your work as you see fit, without the typical restrictions imposed by other blogging platforms.

Installing Jekyll

Following the instructions on the Jekyll and Ubuntu web sites, I used the following to install the required software and get a skeleton established for my blog.

sudo apt-get install ruby1.9.1-dev
sudo apt-get install rdiscount
sudo gem install jekyll
sudo apt-get install rake
jekyll new myblog

What is produced looks like this:

To see how this will be rendered on within a browser, execute jekyll serve --watch within ~/myblog and then set your browse to http://localhost:4000.

Moving Blog from WordPress.com

Next, I want to import my old website to myblog and convert it to Jekyll. First I need to export my site, and I can do this by going to https://jeffskinnerbox.wordpress.com/wp-admin/export.php and, executing the commands there, place the HTML file created in a temporary place. Then install these tools:

sudo gem install jekyll-import --pre
sudo gem install hpricot

To do the actual conversion and down loading of the site, you use the command:

jekyll import wordpressdotcom --source ~/tmp/jeff039sskinnerbox.wordpress.2013-08-14.xml

Creating Your Local Git Repository

cd ~/myblog
git init
git add .
git commit -m 'Initial commit'

Creating the GitHub Page (Remote Repository)

Github Pages provides a simple service for serving up static HTML from a GitHub repository. Itâs the perfect place for project documentation, when combined with Jekyll it can support a blog. The post Getting started with GitHub Pages provide a good overview. The steps to get the web site up and running go like this:

  • On my GitHub site, I created a new Repository call jeffskinnerbox.github.com
  • From the PC, load the web site to the GitHub Repository:
git remote add origin http://github.com/jeffskinnerbox/jeffskinnerbox.github.com
git push -u origin master
  • Verify that your web page is available by going to http://jeffskinnerbox.github.com. This could take up to 10 minutes for GitHub the first time.

Using a Custom Domain Name

GitHub Pages allows you to direct a domain name of your choice at your GitHub Page. My custom domain name is www.jeffskinnerbox.me. To do the setup, I found the postings Setting up a custom domain with Pages and Setting the DNS for GitHub Pages on Namecheap helpful. It goes like this:

  1. Telling the GitHub server to serve from the custom domain by creating a file named CNAME in the root of your site and put string with the domain (i.e. jeffskinnerbox.me) into the file.
  2. Go to your Domain Name Registrar and make the changes outline in the posts reference above. It may take as long as 24 hours for these changes to take effect.

Closing

All in all, I am very pleased with Jekyll so far. It did take a little longer than Iâd have thought to migrate this blog as it is from WordPress, while also preserving the siteâs characteristics, but it didnât take too long and I love the results. I doubt I would ever want to look back!

Life hasÂ taught me thatÂ all good planning is ultimatelyÂ undone, and at some point, you must improvise. Â That has also proven true for this quest to up grade my computation. Â Specifically:

    • After ordering all the hardware, it came to me that it was dumb to attempt to reuse my old semi-reliable, slow CD drive. Â So I purchase the HP 24X Multiformat DVD/CD Writer (dvd1260i) at Best Buy for 40 dollars.
    • I discovered that the my old PC hadÂ ATAÂ hard drivesÂ (commonly called an IDE drive) and my new Mobo onlyÂ supportsÂ SATAÂ (SATA 3Gb/s & 6GB/s and it includes an external eSATA port). Â  This blows my plan to reuse my existing hard drives … stupid me, I should have checked. Â I did a quick scan for ATAÂ controllerÂ cards and found a few (not many) for 15 to 30 dollars. Â I could buy the card and make this work but it doesn’t seem like a good investment. Â The drives are 400G drives and has a maximum data transfer rate of about 133MB/s (i.e. ATA/66). Â The maximum data transfer rates of SATA II and SATA III are 300 MB/s and 600 MB/s, respectively. Â I can buy aÂ Seagate - Barracuda 500GB SATA IIÂ Internal Hard Drive for $70. Â Given my objective to increase the performance of my computing experience, buying a new SATA III hard drive should have been part of theÂ originalÂ plan.
    • After reading up on RAID andÂ the Intel Rapid Storage Technology (RST), I concluded that it would be best to do a Software Raid and not use RST.
    • While I assumed in myÂ originalÂ plan that I would dual boot the box with Linux and MS Windows, the comment fromÂ armahillo@gmail.comÂ convincedÂ me of what I suspected I should do; and that was to make wine,Â mono, andÂ PlayOnLinuxÂ work for me. Â While I haven’t stressed them, so far so good. Â I have not installed VirtualBox and I suspect I will not … unless I get desperate.
    • I was planning to reuse my old keyboard and mouse, but you know, I hated that keyboard and the mouse was alreadyÂ actingÂ badly and about to die on me. Â So I ended up replacing them with sometime worthy of my new system.

Configuring Ubuntu

You’ll find many recommendations on how to jazz up a newlly install Ubuntu system. Â I found some of these suggestions useful:
    • To Do List After installing Ubuntu 13.04 aka Raring Ringtail OS
    • Things/Tweaks to do after Install of Ubuntu 13.04 Raring Ringtail
    • Top things to do after installing Ubuntu 13.04

Installing “dot” Files

Like may, over the years I have made a large time investment in tuning my .bashrc, .vimrc, and other such resource files. Â I installed my beloved “dot” files from my Git repository.

Installing Google Chromeâs Native PDF Reader in Chromium

Chromium is aÂ fully open-source version of Google’s Chrome, and forÂ licensing reasons, it doesn’t come packaged with the integrated Flash or a native PDF reader. Â Lucky, there is a work around and that is documented here:Â Use Google Chromeâs Native PDF reader in Chromium.

Installing My Squeeze Box

I have a SqueezeBox device in my workshop for playing music. Â On my old PC, I had installed the SlimServer which would provide the music stream. Â I want to now reestablish that capability on the Linux box. The postÂ How to Use Squeezebox With Ubuntu and the Logitech SqueezeBox Wiki gives you all the information you should need.

The Ubuntu (Debian) software for theÂ SqueezeCenterÂ or now called the Logitech Media ServerÂ (formerly known as SlimServer) is maintained by Logitech, and therefore, will not be installed via get-apt. Â To make it part of the package resource list (used to locate archives of the package distribution system in use on the system), you need to update the /etc/apt/sources.list file. Â To do this, do the following:

sudo vim /etc/apt/sources.list

Scroll to the bottom of the file and enter the following information and then save:

## This software is not part of Ubuntu, but is offered by Logitech for the Logitech Media ServerÂ (formerly known as SqueezeCenter or SlimServer).
deb http://debian.slimdevices.com stable main

Now do the following:

sudo apt-get remove --purgeÂ logitechmediaserver
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get installÂ logitechmediaserver

Now open a browser and type “http://desktop:9000” as the URL, where “desktop” is the name of your Linux system. Â This brings you to a Squeezebox interface to configure the system.

If you want to start/stop Logitech Media ServerÂ manually you can run: sudo /etc/init.d/logitechmediaserver stop and sudo /etc/init.d/logitechmediaserver start

Configuring Samsung SCX-4521F Printer/Scanner

When it comes to printers and scanners, Ubuntu advices that you should simply plug it in and try! Ubuntu claims that if it’s a newer model USB scanner / printer, it is likely that it will work immediately without any further driver or software installations. I did this with my multifunction Samsung SCX-4521F, which is a printer / scanner combination, and the printer function worked but the scanner did not.

After a bit of research, I discovered that Ubuntu uses Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) for printer management. CUPS is the standards-based, open source printing system developed by Apple for OS X and other UNIX-like operating systems. Assuming CUPS is installed (and it appeares to be with the Ubuntu package), you can use a web browser to access it features. To do this, open your web browser and got to http://localhost:631/. You’ll find there an overview of CUPS, administrative functions, and even command-line utilities.

I also discovered that SANE (Scanner Access Now Easy) is the Linux way of scanning. SANE supports a great many scanners, and the community around SANE adds support for more scanners all the time. They claim, by and large, you should simple plug them in and your ready to scan. However, some scanners, like mine, require more effort.

SANE isn’t typically installed with the Ubuntu distribution, but you can install SANE via

sudo apt-get install sane xsane libsane-extras

SANE supplies a utility called scanimage that is a command-line interface to control image acquisition devices such as flatbed scanners or cameras. When I ran it, I got the following results

$ scanimage --list-devices

No scanners were identified. If you were expecting something different,
check that the scanner is plugged in, turned on and detected by the
sane-find-scanner tool (if appropriate). Please read the documentation
which came with this software (README, FAQ, manpages).

Some more web research told me that my printer is a Xerox manufactured product and I needed to install the Samsung Unified Linux Driver. I did the repository setup and package install recommended at The Samsung Unified Linux Driver Repository. The install I did was

sudo apt-get install suld-driver-4.00.39 suld-configurator-2-qt4

I then added my login user to the scanner group via sudo usermod -a -G scanner jeff. I ran the command sane-find-scanner to see if I’m now able to detect the scanner, and I got the following disappointing results.

$ sudo sane-find-scanner

  # sane-find-scanner will now attempt to detect your scanner. If the
  # result is different from what you expected, first make sure your
  # scanner is powered up and properly connected to your computer.

  # No SCSI scanners found. If you expected something different, make sure that
  # you have loaded a kernel SCSI driver for your SCSI adapter.

could not fetch string descriptor: Pipe error
could not fetch string descriptor: Pipe error
  # No USB scanners found. If you expected something different, make sure that
  # you have loaded a kernel driver for your USB host controller and have setup
  # the USB system correctly. See man sane-usb for details.

  # Not checking for parallel port scanners.

  # Most Scanners connected to the parallel port or other proprietary ports
  # can't be detected by this program.

At this point, I did some back tracking and discovered the following article: How do I get the scanner to work on a Samsung SCX 4521F Multi function printer? The work already done above covers step 1 of this article and step 2 isn’t relevant (since I can already print). I need to perform step 3, that is

sudo apt-get install samsungmfp-scanner

Now I re-ran the command scanimage --list-devices and got the following

$ scanimage --list-devices
device `smfp:SAMSUNG SCX-4x21 Series on USB:0' is a SAMSUNG SCX-4x21 Series on USB:0 Scanner

but the sudo sane-find-scanner got the same “could not fetch string descriptor: Pipe error” error message when done earlier.

After some more research and using lsusb | grep Samsung and cat /lib/udev/rules.d/40-libsane.rules | grep 3419, I discover there is no udev rule for the SCX-4521F scanner. Therefore, I place the following lines in /lib/udev/rules.d/40-libsane.rules

# Samsung SCX-4521F
ATTRS{idVendor}=="04e8", ATTRS{idProduct}=="3419", ENV{libsane_matched}="yes"

This still didn’t give me a good run for sudo sane-find-scanner but the command scanimage --test did give passing results. Given this, I proceeded to using xsane to test out some scanning (it worked!). xsane is a X Window application and produces it output in PNM format. You can convert this format to PDF (and many other formats) via the utility convert (e.g. convert outfile.pnm outfile.pdf).

iPod Support

Ubuntu comes with Rhythmbox as its music playing application and can be used to synch with a iPod. Also, you’ll want to install several Rhythmbox plugins. That can be done via

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:fossfreedom/rhythmbox-plugins
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:phw/musicbrainz
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install rhythmbox-plugin-complete

After installing any of the above Rhythmbox plugins, enable them from the main menu: Rhythmbox > Plugins.

Setting-Up Harmony Remote

I have the Logitech Harmony 650 Universal Remote ControlÂ for my home theater system. Â To program the device, it must beÂ tetheredÂ to a web site via a Windows or Mac PC. Â The Harmony web site doesÂ referenceÂ some Linux support done by others. Â The posting “How to set up a Harmony remote using Linux” and “Logitech Harmony Universal Remote Linux Software Support” give you the basics of what you need to do. Â Within these sites you lean about the utilitiesÂ concordance andÂ congruity. The first utility provides most of the functionality of the Windows software provided by Logitech and the secondÂ is a GUI application for programming Logitech Harmony remote using concordance. Â To install these utilities, do the following:

sudo apt-get install concordance
sudo apt-get install congruity

You also have to configure the web browser to ask what to do with download links. It is best to use Firefox and you canÂ configureÂ downloads via: Edit->Preferences->General->Downloads->Always ask me where to save files.

Now plug the remote into the PC using the provided cable, and enter the command:Â sudo concordance -i -v. Â You should get a bunch of data and the word “Success”,Â verifyingÂ that you can talk to the device.

Now go through the following process:

    1. Plug in the remote via the provided USB cable.
    2. Visit the Harmony Remote’s member site URL. Â This appears to be a legacy support site and Logitech site listed in the documentation with the device will not work under Linux.
    3. Create an account or login into your existing account.
    4. Skip/ignore the âyou need to update your softwareâ steps, and eventually a download prompt appears.
    5. Choosing âopenâ rather than âsaveâ impressively results in the Congruity graphical setup up launching.
    6. Step through the setup boxes as prompted.

Setting-Up Keyboard & Mouse

To improve my drivingÂ experience, I purchased the Logitech Wireless Illuminated Keyboard K800 and the Logitech M510 Wireless Mouse. These devices use theÂ Logitech Unifying wireless technology, which allows a singleÂ wireless receiver to connect with multiple Unifying devices. Â I plugged in the mouse’sÂ receiverÂ  and in short order the mouse was working. I was a bit concerned about the ability of theÂ receiverÂ to support multiple device (i.e. the keyboard)Â simultaneouslyÂ under Linux. Doing a quick search I found a post discussing how to do the device pairing under Linux. Â To install the ltunifyÂ pairing software,Â and do the pairing, do the following:

cd ~/src
git clone https://git.lekensteyn.nl/ltunify.git
cd ltunify
make install-home
  • To list the devices that are paired:Â sudo ltunify list
  • To pair a device:Â sudo ltunify pair, thenÂ turn your wireless device off and on to start pairing.
  • To unpairÂ a device:Â sudo ltunify unpair mouse
  • To get help: sudo ltunity --help

Mouse Xbindkeys

The M510 mouseÂ has extra buttons on its left side and the scroll wheel Â has a side-to-side click, but out of the box,the don’t do anything under Linux. Â It would be nice toÂ make use of these extra buttons. Â To address this problem, I found pointers in these posts:Â How to get all those extra mouse buttons to work,Â How do I remap certain keys,Â Â Mouse shortcuts with xbindkeys,Â andÂ Guide for setup Performance MX mouse on Linux (with KDE).

Basically, using Xbindkeys, I want to map the mouse buttons with desired actions.Â I want to setup the M510 mouse extra buttons as follows:

    • Left-side Button:Â up mapped to Page Up andÂ down mapped to Page Down
    • Scroll Wheel:Â move left mapped to CopyÂ andÂ move right mapped to Paste
    • Scroll Wheel:Â pressÂ mapped toÂ Paste
xevÂ prints the contents of X events byÂ creating a window and then asks the X Server to send it events whenever anything happens to the window. Â It’s sort of aÂ keyboard and mouse events sniffer. Â If we know what event name the X Server gives to our buttons, then we can remap them. Using this program, we find out the following:
    • Left-side Button:Â upÂ is known by the X Server as button 9
    • Left-side Button:Â downÂ is known by the X Server as button 8
    • Scroll Wheel:Â move leftÂ is known by the X Server as button 6
    • Scroll Wheel:Â move rightÂ is known by the X Server as button 7
    • Scroll Wheel:Â pressÂ is known by the X Server asÂ button 2
Now we need a mechanism to re-map mouse (or keyboard) button inputs. Â Xbindkeys is is a X Windows program that enables us to bind commands to certain keys or key combinations on the keyboard and it will also work for the mouse. Â The file Â ~/.xbindkeysrcÂ is whatÂ xbindkeysÂ uses as a configuration file to link a command to a key/button on your keyboard/mouse. Â There is also xbindkeys_config is an easy to use gtk program for configuring xbindkeys. To install these tools, do the following:

sudo apt-get install xautomationÂ xbindkeys xbindkeys-config

To create your initial xbindkeysÂ configuration file, just run the following command:

xbindkeys --defaults > $HOME/.xbindkeysrc

The syntax of the contents of .xbindskesrc is simple and is illustrated below:

# short comment
    "command to start"
        associated key

The "command to start" is simply a shell command (that you can run from a terminal), Â and "associated key" is the key or button.

Now, using an editor, update the .xbindkeysrc file to include the following:

# Do a Page Down when mouse left-side down button is pressed
"xte 'key Page_Down'"
    b:8
# Do a Page Up when mouse left-side up button is pressed
"xte 'key Page_Up'"
    b:9
# Move scroll wheel to the left to copy text
"xte 'keydown Control_L' 'keydown Shift_L' 'key c' 'keyup Control_L' 'keyup Shift_L'"
    b:6
# Move scroll wheel to the right to paste text
"xte 'keydown Control_L' 'keydown Shift_L' 'key v' 'keyup Control_L' 'keyup Shift_L'"
    b:7
# Press scroll wheel to paste text
"xte 'keydown Control_L' 'keydown Shift_L' 'key v' 'keyup Control_L' 'keyup Shift_L'"
    b:2

To activate any modification of the .xbindkeysrcÂ configuration file, your have to restart xbindkeys. Â  This can be done via:

pkill xbindkeys
xbindkeys

Other useful resources are:

    • xte is a program that generates fake input using the XTest extension
    • xvkbd is a virtual (graphical) keyboard program for X Window System which provides facility to enter characters onto other X clients by clicking on a keyboard displayed on the screen.
    • xbindkeys_show is a program to show the grabbing keys used in xbindkeys
    • xmodmap is a utility for modifying keymaps and pointer button mappings in Xorg.

Moving from SplashID to KeePass

I have been using the MS Windows basedÂ SplashID to storeÂ passwords, credit cards, account numbers, etc. securely on my PC and cell phone. Â I got it to work under Wine but I’m considering Linux alternatives. Â I’m growing tired of purchasing SplashID licenses and the user interface looks like it was designed in the 1970’s. Â I came across “Five Best Password Managers” which gave me the incentive to check out KeePass. Â KeePass is a cross platform,Â open source password manager. Â It is extendable via itsÂ plugin framework, where additional functionality can be added. Â It looks like I can use Dropbox andÂ KeePassDroid to get the data on my cell phone. Â I found these sites useful to get the job done:
    • Sync Passwords Across Computers And Android With KeePass
    • How to Use Dropbox as the Ultimate Password Syncer
The first step was to get KeePass installed in Ubuntu. Â I found it on the Ubuntu Software Center or you can use:

sudo apt-get install keepass2Â keepass2-doc

I then exported the contents of my SplashID database to a CSV file and imported it into keepass2. Â I set up the KeePass2 database within my Dropbox folder. Â This way, it can be scych’ed with my cell phone. I then installed KeePassDroid on my cell phone, pointing it at the database with the cell phones Dropbox. Â KeePassDroid is a port of the KeePass password safe for the Android platform.

There is some cleanup of the fields within the KeePass2 database, but the data is now accessable on both my PC and my cell phone.

Installing Wine

Wine allows you to run many Windows programs on Linux. Instead of simulating internal Windows logic like a virtual machine or emulator, Wine translates Windows API calls into Linux calls. Â I used the following to install Wine:

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:ubuntu-wine/ppa
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install wine

Using Wine on Windows programs can be as simple Â or complex, it all depends on the program. Â Ubuntu provides some guidance on how to use Wine, alsoÂ check out Wine Documentation andÂ Wine HowTo.

As of this writing of the post, the only thing I loaded via Wine was SplashID, which worked without any challenges.

Installing PlayOnLinux

PlayOnLinux is based on Wine, and so profits from all its features, yet it keeps the user from having to deal with all its complexity. Â I also install this package, in part because it comes pre-configured to load some popular tools. Â I used it to install Internet Explore (sometimes its the only browser you can get to work on a site), and Kindle.

Installing RAID

RAID is an acronym for Redundant Array of Independent Disks and RAID as the first tier in your data protection strategy.Â It uses multiple hard disks storing the same data to protect against some degree of physical disk failure. The amount of protection it affords depends upon the type of RAID used. Â I’m not going to go into all the types of RAID, nor their benefits, but you can find much of this information, and much more, in the following links:
    • Raid
    • FakeRaidHowto
    • 10 Surprising Facts About RAID
    • Mdadm
In my case, I had an existing disk drive (non-RAID), loaded with data, and I wanted to add an additional drive to make it a RAID. Â This presents some challenges since you’re attempting to preserve the data. Â In this regard, I found the following links helpful:
    • Installing Raid 1 on Existing Ubuntu Server
    • Using MDADM to add RAID 1 setup to existing data drive
    • Convert a single drive system to RAID
    • Setting up RAID on an existing Debian/Ubuntu installation
    • Software Raid 1 Setup
    • Configure Software RAID1 Array In Linux
I had already installed one SSD and one HHD disk drives in my system. Â I then installed a third drive that matched the HHD drive. Â My 128GB SSD has the device name of /dev/sda1 and mounted as /boot. Â The currently installed 1TB SATA HDD has the device name of /dev/sdb1 and mounted as /home. Â The newly installÂ 1TB SATA HDD has the device name of /dev/sdc.

Description of the procedures I used to create the RAID is as follows:

    • PhysicallyÂ install the additionalÂ hard drive.
    • Install mdadm, which is theÂ Linux utility used to manage software RAID devices.

sudo apt-get install mdadm
    • Partition the newly installed disk. Use the following inputs: n to establish a logic partition, p to make it a primary partition, 1 Â should be the partition number, use the same sectors as the currently installed drive,Â t to set the partition type, fd hex code type,Â p to print what the partition table will look like, w toÂ write all of the changes to disk.
sudo fdisk /dev/sdc
    • Create a single-disk RAID-1 array (aka degraded array)Â with the existing hard drive. (Note the “missing” keyword is specified as one of the devices. We are going to fill this missing device later with the new drive.)
sudo mdadm --create /dev/md0 --level=1 --raid-devices=2 missing /dev/sdc1
    • At this point, if you do aÂ sudo fdisk -l | grep '^Disk', you see a new disk, that being /dev/md0. Â This is the RAID but not yet fully created.
    • Make the file system (ext3 type like the currently installed hard drive) on the RAIDÂ device.
sudo mkfs -t ext3 -j -L RAID-ONE /dev/md0
    • Make a mount point for the RAID and mount the device.
sudo mkdir /mnt/raid1
sudo mount /dev/md0 /mnt/raid1</code></p>
    • Copy over the files form theÂ originalÂ hard drive to the new hard drive using rsync.
sudo rsync -avxHAXS --delete --progress /home/* /mnt/raid1
    • Just Â in case of aÂ disaster, copy theÂ originalÂ hard drive to the SSD /dev/sda1 root file system as /home_backup.
sudo rsync -avxHAXS --delete --progress /home /home_backup
    • After the copy, to see the status of the RAID, use the commandÂ sudo mdadm --detail /dev/md0. Â What you see is that the /dev/sdc1 drives is in “active sync ” state but noÂ referenceÂ to the other drive. Â When you doÂ cat /proc/mdstatÂ you see “md0 : active raid1 sdc1[1]” butÂ againÂ noÂ referenceÂ to the other drive.
    • Edit yourÂ /etc/fstabÂ file and edit all references ofÂ /dev/sdb1Â toÂ /dev/md0Â and reboot the system. Â With this, /dev/md0 will be used as /home on the next boot. This will free up the existing hard drive so it can be made ready for the RAID.
    • With fdisk,Â re-partitionÂ /dev/sdb1 with a partition of type fd. Use the following inputs: n to establish a logic partition, p to make it a primary partition, 1 Â should be the partition number, use the same sectors as the currently installed drive, t to set the partition type, fd hex code type, p to print what the partition table will look like, w to write all of the changes to disk.
sudo fdisk /dev/sdb1
    • Add /dev/sdb1 to your existing RAID array.
mdadm /dev/md0 --add /dev/sdb1
    • The RAID array will now start to rebuild so that the two drives have the same data. Use the following command to check the status of the rebuild.
sudo mdadm -D /dev/md0
    • For Ubuntu, it seems it is also necessary to update the /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf file. If this is not done, the RAID device will not be mounted when you reboot the system. The solution is to run the following command on your system, once the RAID drive has been configured:
sudo cp /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf_backup
sudo mdadm --detail --scan >> /etc/mdadm/mdadm.conf

item.title: GNU Radio and Gqrx SDR Receiver
item.description:
In my last post, I was using the RTL2832 TV tunerÂ dongle to get a simple Software Defined Radio (SDR)Â operational. Â I wanted to use the SDR# program as myÂ receiverÂ but found that the MS Windows tool would not work and so IÂ targetedÂ Gqrx as an alternative. Gqrx is dependent on theÂ GNU Radio. Â So in this post, I plan to get Gqrx and GNU Radio up and operational with theÂ RTL-SDR dongle. Â I spend some time with other tools to help further verify (with mixed success)Â that GNU Radio is working.

The contain here comes from multiple source and I attempt to list those sources below. Â For a good video to get a sense of what your in for, check out this video. Also, this post covers many of the topics here.

GNU Radio is a free & open-source software development toolkit that provides signal processing blocks to implement software defined radios. It can be used with readily-available low-cost external RF hardware to create software-defined radios, or without hardware in a simulation-like environment. It is being used in hobbyist, academic, and commercial environments to support both wireless communications research and real-world radio systems.Â 

Gqrx is an experimental AM, FM and Single Side Band (SSB) software defined receiver implemented usingÂ GNU Radio and the Qt GUI toolkit.Â Currently it works on Linux and can use the RTL_SDR dongles as input source.

AlsoÂ withinÂ this post, I venture out from gqrx to examine a few other tools. Â I don’t cover muchÂ territory, nor have much success. Â The insperation to examine these other tools comes mainly from the lengthy post “RTL-SDR and GNU Radio with Realtek RTL2832U [Elonics E4000/Raphael Micro R820T] software defined radio receiver“. Â Also check out “Getting Started with GNU Radio and RTL-SDR (on Backtrack)“.

Build GNU Radio on Ubuntu

The GNU Radio web site has specificÂ instructionsÂ and a build script for installing it on Ubuntu (I’m using version 13.04). Â This process claims it may take 1-2 hours to do the install (for me it ran in 1 hour 14 minutes). Â The steps are as follows:

cd ~/src
mkdir ~/gnuradio
cd ~/gnuradio
wget http://www.sbrac.org/files/build-gnuradio && chmod a+x ./build-gnuradio && ./build-gnuradioÂ --verbose

When prompted, tell it to proceed and give it sudoÂ privilegeÂ by typing “Y”. Because of the --verbose option, you will see a lot of text whizzing by as the build-gnuradio script does its thing. Youâll also see a percentage complete indicator as the script works its way down it tasks.

The GNU Radio build creates a large variety of tools which get installed into /usr/local/bin. Â You also notice that tools not directly related to GNU Radio are also created. I’ll leave it for another time toÂ understandÂ andÂ explainÂ the GNU RadioÂ environment.

The “Hello World” of GNU Radio

To verify that the software is working, best thing is to create the typical “Hello, World” program, just we might have done for our first foray into C++, Python, or other programming language. Â In the world of GNU Radio, this program has come to be the phone dial tone. To do this, I followed the videoÂ The “Hello World” of GNU Radio: Dial ToneÂ and theÂ gnuradio.org. Â I did this using the GNU Radio CompanionÂ (executable located atÂ /usr/local/bin/gnuradio-companion). Â GNU Radio Companion (GRC) is a graphical tool for creating signal flow graphical models and generating Python source code for the model created.

GRC’s generated flow and code for theÂ ”Hello, World” program is listed below. The Python code for the dial tone program was placed in the home directory, and in my case, it was called dail_tone.py. While it can be executed via the gnuradio-companion, it can also be executed via python dial_tone.py. The user interface for the GRC and theÂ correspondingÂ Python code it generated is listed below:

#!/usr/bin/env python
##################################################
# Gnuradio Python Flow Graph
# Title: Dial Tone
# Author: Jeff Irland
# Description: "Hello, World" program - produces phone dial tone
# Generated: Sat Jun 22 21:24:56 2013
##################################################

from gnuradio import analog
from gnuradio import audio
from gnuradio import blocks
from gnuradio import eng_notation
from gnuradio import gr
from gnuradio import window
from gnuradio.eng_option import eng_option
from gnuradio.gr import firdes
from gnuradio.wxgui import fftsink2
from gnuradio.wxgui import forms
from gnuradio.wxgui import scopesink2
from grc_gnuradio import wxgui as grc_wxgui
from optparse import OptionParser
import wx

class dial_tone(grc_wxgui.top_block_gui):

    def __init__(self):
        grc_wxgui.top_block_gui.__init__(self, title="Dial Tone")

When the GRC flow execution button is pressed, the scope and FFT plots are are created as shown below:

The build for GNU Radio also installs the RTL-SDR software, so it would be wise to test GNU Radio with the RTL_SDR hardware and make sure everything is operating as expected. Â I want to make a simple FMÂ receiver,Â comparableÂ to what was done viaÂ rtl_fm inÂ RTL-SDR â Software Defined Radio (SDR) for $20. Something equivalent to:

rtl_fm -W -f 99.5M | play -r 32k -t raw -e signed-integer -b 16 -c 1 -V1 -

Using the following postings as a guide:
    • How To Build an FM Receiver with the USRP in Less Than 10 Minutes
    • Construction of an FM Receiver
    • Assembling an FM Receiver Like BlazesÂ by GNU Radio
    • Simple FM Receiver with OsmoSDR in GNURadio
    • RTL2832U Based Wide Band FM receiver using GNU RADIO
I had sufficient success to convince myself that GNU Radio was work.

Building Gqrx on Ubuntu

Gqrx is a software defined AM, FM and SSB software defined radio receiverÂ for RTL-SDR based dongles (as well asÂ the Universal Software Radio Peripherals and Osmo SDR devices).Â Â It features a Â Qt GUI. Â As a QT program, you’ll need to make sure you have QT4 installed (versionÂ 5 will not work) and that you have the qtcreator tool is installed:

sudo apt-get install qt4-default
sudo apt-get install phonon-backend-gstreamer

Now download the source for Gqrx via its page on GitHub Â and extract it into your target directory. The postingÂ Getting Started With RTL-SDRÂ and the README on the GitHub site where useful in understanding how to do the install. Â I did the following:

git clone git://github.com/csete/gqrx.git
cd gqrx
qmake gqrx.pro
make

At this point, you should find the gqrx executable in ~/src/gqrx directory. Â Start up via ./gqrx and you’ll get the screen below (or set your values to equal this):

Click “OK” and the screen below will pop up. Â Make sure you have the RTL-SDRÂ dongleÂ plugged in and select the button on the top left to start processing data. Â I have tuned the radio to a local FM station at 85.7MHz and listen to WashingtonÂ NationalsÂ vs. PhilliesÂ baseball!

Building Multimode Radio Receiver

This radioÂ receiverÂ is capable of demodulating muitiple modes, specifically AM, FM, USB, LSB , WFM. TV-FM, PAL-FM. It’s easy to use and Â has an automated scanning and spectral zoom features where clicking on the spectrogram or panorama to tune to the frequency of interest.

Multimode documentation isÂ sparseÂ to nonÂ existent. The posts “Using the Realtek RTL2832 USB âdongleâ as a gnuradio multimode receiver” and “RTL-SDR and GNU Radio with Realtek RTL2832U [Elonics E4000/Raphael Micro R820T] software defined radio receiver” and “Getting Started with GNU Radio and RTL-SDR (on Backtrack)” gave someÂ importantÂ hints on how to install multimode and get it operational. Â I did the following:

cd ~
svn co https://www.cgran.org/svn/projects/multimode/trunk/ ~/src/multimode
make install

When I executed multimode.py, it didn’t product a display. Â I suspect its someÂ subtle Python code problem, or more likely. Â incompatibility with the latest GNU Radio libraries.Â Â For now, I’m going to abandon this.

GNU Radio Signal Scanner

gr-scan is a program Â built upon GNU Radio, rtl-sdr, and the OsmoSDR Source Block. Â This receiver constantly changes frequencies in a set order looking for a frequency that has someone transmitting.Â It is intended to scan a range of frequencies and print a list of discovered signals. Â Installation involved the following steps:

cd ~./src
mkdir gr-scan
cd gr-scan

with your browser, download:Â http://www.techmeology.co.uk/gr-scan/gr-scan-2012082301.tar.gz

gzip -d gr-scan-2012082301.tar.gz
tar -xvvfÂ gr-scan-2012082301.tar
cd gr-scan-2012082301
make

When I attempted to do the make, it complained about missing Gun Radio files. Â I suspect the GNU Radio libraries andÂ includeÂ files are layed outÂ differentlyÂ since the time gr-scan was designed (August of 2012). Â I’m leaving fixing this to another time.

What’s Next

In this and theÂ previousÂ SDRÂ posts, I focused on getting a taste of the technology withoutÂ committingÂ myselfÂ to much of an effort. Â I really need to study and understand the tools that I have assembled. I still need to do a great deal moreÂ studyingÂ of Â the radio spectrumÂ itself … I feel like I’m wondering in the dark most of the time.

Also,Â I feel that I’m very limited by the antenna I’m presently using (theÂ pitifulÂ dipole that came with the RTLÂ dongle). Â I’m thinking of building a betterÂ antenna. Â Maybe try to pickup aÂ NOAA weather satellites, with itsÂ distinctiveÂ audioÂ signal when demodulated, and decode one of itsÂ satellite weather photos …. maybe.

Another problem with the RTL-SDR is that its internal oscillator is cheap Â and drifts, resulting in clock errors with Â many kHz of frequency display error in SDR - depending on a band you’re listening to. Â This is very annoying if you use your dongle as a radio scanner - what’s the point of knowing frequency of a transmitter if it’s almost random on your SDR? Â Â This frequency error is linear across the spectrum, and can be adjusted in most SDR programs by entering a PPM (parts per million) offset value. Â So I need to calculate this error offset so I can Â calibrate the SDR software.

item.title: Linux Reboot ... or ... My System is Frozen and I Can't Get Up!
item.description:
While I was building theÂ environmentÂ for my Linux box, Â I ran into some problems with Ubuntu. Â I found myself with frozenÂ screensÂ or booted up into blank screens and other such things. Â Seems that Ubuntu 13.04 is currently a bit unstable or I just screwed things up badly … a little of both I suspect. I managed to get through these problems, but too often I got desperate and I hitting the on/off switch to get the box rebooted. Â Doing this can result inÂ corruptedÂ files and other such nasty things. Â So this motivated me toÂ researchÂ the “correct” way to get out of these Linux near deathÂ experiences.

The golden nugget here isÂ actuallyÂ at the end of this posting, that is theÂ Magic SysRq Key. Â This gem can get you out of most any freeze but I provide more here since the alternatives might be less intrusive.

Stopping a Running Process

While this post’s focus is on how to rebootÂ Linux, keep in mind thatÂ sometimesÂ the problem that your attempting to solve may beÂ handledÂ via a simpler approach. Â Specifically, maybe you just need to kill a running process.

In the Bash shell, you can use job control:

    • Ctrl+C â halts the current command
    • Ctrl+Z â stops the current command, resume withÂ fg in the foreground or bg in the background
    • Ctrl+D â log out of current session, similar to exit
On a Desktop version of Linux, there are normally six text consoles sessions available and one graphics session. Â You could leave a frozen GUI, and go to a console screen to kill an offending process:
    • You can access the consoles by pressing CTRL + ALT + Fx (where Fx is a function key on the keyboard from F1 to F6).
    • Once you enter one of the consoles, you will be prompted for user name and password. Enter them and then youâll reach a command prompt. Â Now you can kill the offending process using the kill command.
    • To switch back to the graphic session, just click CTRL + ALT + F7.
The process “killing” could be done via the recommendedÂ kill -SIGTERMÂ pidÂ Â or the more forcefulÂ kill -SIGKILLÂ pid. There are also versions of these tools,Â killallÂ andÂ pkill,Â that use the name of the process as anÂ argumentÂ instead of the process ID.

xkillÂ is a utility for forcing the X server to close connections to clients.Â Closing an X application that has become unresponsive, orÂ misbehavingÂ in general. Execute xkill, and once it’s running, you simply click on the window you wish to Â kill, and itÂ performsÂ aÂ kill -9.

When Kill -9 Does Not Work

You are supposed to be able to kill any process withÂ kill -9Â pid, but you may come across a process that just will not die. Usually this happens when you are trying to kill aÂ zombie process or defunct process. These are processes that are dead and have exited, but they remain asÂ zombies in the process list. The kernel keeps them in the process list until the parentÂ processÂ retrieves the exit status code by calling the wait() system call. This does not usually happen with daemon processes because they detach themselves from their parent process and are adopted by the init process (PID=1) which will automatically call wait() to clear them out of the process list.

You may sometimes see the daemon defunct PID in the process list for a brief moment before it gets cleaned up by the init process. You don’t have to worry about these. You can also end up with an unkillable process if a process is stuck waiting for the kernel to finish something. This usually happens when the kernel is waiting for I/O. Where you see this most often is with network filesystems such as NFS and SaMBa that have disconnected uncleanly. This also happens when a drive fails or if someone unplugs a cable to a mounted drive. If the device had a memmapped file or was used for swap then you may be really screwed. Any kernel calls that flush IO may hang forever waiting for the device to respond.

Zombies can be identified in the output from the process status commandÂ psÂ by the presence of a “Z” in the “STAT” column. Zombies that exist for more than a short period of time typically indicate a bug in the parent program, or just an uncommon decision to reap children. Â A zombie process is not the same as an orphan process. An orphan process is a process that is still executing, but whose parent has died. They do not become zombie processes; instead, they are adopted by init (process ID 1), which waits on its children.

Standard Reboot Commands

The vast majority of your systm shut downs or reboots will follow one of these two forms. Â The first willÂ haltÂ the system so you can power it off and the second will reboot the system:

shutdown -h now shutdown -r now

shutdown is theÂ preferredÂ and the safest ways to stop Linux. Never the less, in theÂ traditionÂ of Unix, Linux gives you more than one Â way to accomplish this task. Â Â reboot, halt, and poweroffÂ are some additional commands that Linux provides to stop the system. Â These commands can be more “forceful” than shutdown but similar to it.

TheÂ simplicityÂ of these commands give theÂ illusionÂ that the system state of Linux is running or not running. Â It isn’t quite that simple. Â Linux can operate in several states called runlevels.

Linux Runlevels

A runlevel is a preset operating state for the Linux operating system. Â A system can be booted into Â any of several runlevels, each of which is represented by a single digit integer. Each runlevel designates a different system configuration and allows access to a different combination of processes and system resources.

Seven runlevels are supported in the standard Linux kernel. They are:

    • 0 - System Halted:Â  all system activity is stopped, the system can be safely powered down
    • 1 - Single User: Â single superuser is the only active login and no daemons (services) are started. It is mainly used for maintenance.
    • 2 - Multiple Users: multiple users allowed but network filesystem (HFS) is not.
    • 3 - Multiple Users: Â multiple users are allowedÂ command line (i.e., all-text mode);Â the standard runlevel for most servers
    • 4 - User-Definable
    • 5 - Multiple Users: multiple users are allowedÂ graphical user interface; the standard runlevel for most desktop systems
    • 6 - Reboot: just like run level 0 except a reboot is issued,Â used when restarting the system
In the interests of completeness, there is also a runlevel ‘S’ that the system uses on it’s way to another runlevel. Read the man page for the init command for more information, but you can safely skip this for all practical purposes.

By default Linux boots either to runlevel 3 or to runlevel 5. The former permits the system to run all services except for a GUI. The latter allows all services including a GUI.

Booting into a different runlevel can help solve certain problems. For example, if a change made in the X Window System configuration on a machine that has been set up to boot into a GUI has rendered the system unusable, it is possible to temporarily boot into a console (i.e., all-text mode) runlevel (i.e., runlevels 3 or 1) in order to repair the error and then reboot into the GUI. Â Likewise, if a machine will not boot due to a damaged configuration file or will not allow logging-in because of a corrupted /etc/passwd file Â or because of a forgotten password, the problem can solved by first booting into single-user mode (i.e. runlevel 1).

There are two commands for directly reading or manipulating the Linux rumlevels:

    • runlevel - Use the runlevel command to tell you two things: The last run level, and the current run level. Â If the first character isÂ ’N’, it stands for none, meaning there has been no run level change since powering up.
    • telinit - The program responsible for altering the runlevel is init, and it can be called using the telinit command.
The topic of runlevels isÂ actuallyÂ much richer than what is illustrated here. Â It plays a key role in Linux background processes, called services orÂ daemons. Â For more, check out thisÂ Managing Services in Ubuntu, Part I: An Introduction to Runlevels and Part II.

Getting a Login From a Frozen GUI Screen

A not so common problem is when a frozen, full screen X application takes control over your mouse and keyboard and it seems that the only way to regain access to the system is to force a shutdown. Â The fact is, if you could get to a some form of terminalÂ session, you might be able to kill theÂ offendingÂ process and get out of this frozen state. This is whereÂ accessing a console screen by pressing CTRL + ALT + Fx (where Fx is a function key on the keyboard from F1 to F6; and F7 brings you back to the desktop) can be very handy.

The X Server can often be the source of these frozen screen situations, so restarting the X Server may be the solution. Â This can be done via the key combinationÂ Ctrl+Alt+Backspace. Â Keep in mind that you willÂ loses any unsaved data in applications. Â Also, this capability is turned off by default on may Linux systems (includingÂ Ubuntu). Â This was done toÂ avoidÂ confusion by Â people accustom to MS Windows. Â An alternative key combination is as follows:

Press AltGR + SysRQ + K instead (AltGR is the RIGHT ALT button and SysRQ is often labelled “Print Screen”, andÂ rememberÂ to press and hold the keys in the in the right sequence, e.g. starting with ALtGR, and ending with the K(ill) key).

You can turn back on theÂ Ctrl+Alt+Backspace by following the instructions here.

Magic SysRq Key

If the system is completely locks up, or your filesystem fails, there are still alternatives.Â The “magic SysRq key” provides a way to send commands directly to the kernel through the /proc filesystem. It is enabled via a kernel compile time option, CONFIG_MAGIC_SYSRQ, which seems to be standard on most distributions.The magic SysRq keyÂ (or PrintScrn or Print Screen on some keyboards)Â is a key combination understood by the Linux kernel, which allows the user to perform various low-level commands regardless of the system’s state. This is a surprising feature of theÂ kernel but isÂ commonly used to perform a safe reboot of a locked-up Linux computer. Â See this post for some historicalÂ perspectiveÂ of the SysReq key.

To check if the CONFIG_MAGIC_SYSRQ option is enable on yourÂ Linux kernel, check the configuration file that installed toÂ /boot partition. Â Do this via:

cat /boot/config-$(uname -r) | grep CONFIG_MAGIC_SYSRQ

If your get “CONFIG_MAGIC_SYSRQ=y",Â then its enabled on yourÂ kernel.

When running a kernel with SysRq compiled in,Â /proc/sys/kernel/sysrq controls the functions allowed to be invoked viaÂ the SysRq key. Â If the file contains “1“, that means that everyÂ possible SysRq request is allowed. See here for more on the /proc/sys/kernel/sysrq.

To actually reboot the machine there is a well know key sequence to follow: REISUB (or REISUO if you want to turn off the system instead of reboot). Â Basically, if you keep pressed AltGR + SysRq + R and then while you keep pressed AltGR + SysRq you press E, I, S, U, BÂ withÂ about 1 second between each letter (do not type it fast). Your systemÂ will reboot.Â This Â is a safer alternative to just cold rebooting the computer.

Mnemonic for REISUB isÂ Reboot Even If Â System Utterly Broken, and the keys pressed do the following:

    • R - Switch to XLATE mode
    • E - Send Terminate signal to all processes except for init
    • I - Send Kill signal to all processes except for init
    • S - Sync all mounted filesystems
    • U - Remount filesystems as read-only
    • B - Reboot
The magic SysRq key supports more then just the REISUB keys. Â To see the larger range of thing you can do via Magic SysRq Key’sÂ direct communications with the kernel, check out here.

item.title: RTL-SDR Software Defined Radio (SDR) for $20
item.description:
WhileÂ researchingÂ the GNU Radio project, I came upon references to theÂ RTL2832 TV tuners.Â These dongle are made to receive and decode the European standard digital television,Â Digital Video Broadcasting â Terrestrial (DVB-T). (By the way, the North American standard isÂ Advanced Television Systems Committee (ATSC), and not Â compatibleÂ with DVB-T, so this will not work in North America for TV reception.) Â In 2012,Â Antii Palosaari, discovered that there is a device mode for the Realtek DVB-T device chip (RTL2832U) in which raw samples can be captured and transferred to a host computer. This feature enables this device to be used as an inexpensive “frontÂ end” Â for aÂ Software Defined Radio (SDR)Â that could be implemented on a PC or other device.

A SDR provide the ability to sample and record theÂ electromagnetic energy (orÂ radio frequency, called “RF” for short) with noÂ preconceived idea as to the structure of the RF signal. Â In a sense, you can interactÂ with the RF signal in its mustÂ fundamentalÂ form. Â In addition, a SDR allows you toÂ implement, by means of software, a radioÂ communicationÂ system where components that have been typically implemented in hardware.

SDR solutions for the professional-gradeÂ applications andÂ amateurÂ radio have been around for some time, but the appearance ofÂ cheapÂ solutions for the hacker is new. Â There are generalÂ purposeÂ SDRÂ platformsÂ for over $1000, like theÂ Ettus ResearchÂ Universal Software Radio Peripheral (USRP), the $525 SDR-IQ Receiver,Â to the $450Â bladeRFÂ from the Kickstarter Nuand or Great Scott'sÂ DARPA-FundedÂ HackRFÂ for anÂ estimateÂ $300,Â and now the $20 hacker gradeÂ dongleÂ discussed here. Â But unlike most of the otherÂ referencedÂ solutions, Â the dongle Â requires a PC, or some sort of attachedÂ processor, to provide the signal processing.

In all SDR solutions, a significant amounts of theÂ signal processingÂ is handed over to a numerical processor, rather than being done in special-purpose RF hardware. Such a design produces a radio which can receive and transmit widely different radio protocols (referred to as a waveform) based solely on the software used. Â So in a SDR solution, the electromagnetic waveformÂ isÂ rapidlyÂ sampled, the sample values areÂ convertedÂ toÂ numericalÂ values, and these numbers areÂ manipulatedÂ via aÂ disciplineÂ calledÂ digital signal processingÂ (DSP). Â Ultimately, the resulting DSP numerical values produced are converted to an analog signal that goes to aÂ speaker, TV, or other such output device.

The DVB-T dongles can provide a criticalÂ componentÂ of a cheap SDR, since the chip allows transferring the raw I/Q samples to the host. WhatÂ I/Q samplesÂ are is well beyond what I wish toÂ describeÂ here, but let it be said that practical hardware design concerns make I/Q data the critical for signal processing. Â So the fact the dongle does the digital sampling, called aÂ analog-to-digital converter (ADC), and outputs I/Q samples, makes it aÂ valuableÂ asset for a SDR solution.

So how does one get your PC configured to take the dongles I/Q output and create a SDR? Â There is GNU Radio (where this post first begun), but a simplerÂ startingÂ point would be the popular, easy, and open sourceÂ SDR#. Â SDR# canÂ performÂ the required signal processing in anÂ intuitiveÂ user interface (if your into Ham Radio, or bit of a RF hacker, and such). Â Unfortunately, I couldn’t get SDR# (a MS Windows application) to operate under Â Linux and I had to resorted to some simpler utilities.

The Dongle

All this sounds exciting to me (what a geek!) soÂ I purchased from AmazonÂ one of the dongles, specifically theÂ NooElec TV28T v2 USBÂ DVB-T, Â FM+DAB &Â RTL-SDR Receiver, RTL2832U & R820T Tuner, MCX Input.
    • NooElec TV28T - This is the manufacture and model name for the device
    • DVB-T - This device is made toÂ receive and decode the European standard digital television,Â Digital Video Broadcasting â Terrestrial (DVB-T)
    • FM+DAB & RTL-SDR Receiver - The device can alsoÂ receiveÂ FM radio andÂ Digital Audio Broadcasting (DAB) used in several countries, particularly in Europe. RTLSDR is the popular name give to this class of device, which contain the RTL2832U chip, which can be hacked for SDR use.
    • RTL2832U & R820T Tuner - These are the DVB-T demodulatorÂ and TV Tuner chips used in the device.
    • Â MCX Input â Is a 3.6 millimeter (0.14 in) micro coaxial (MCX) coaxial RF connector 30% smaller that Sub-Miniature version B (SMB) connectors that are typically used in the USA. Â MCX is a standard in Europe. It provides broadband capability from DC to 6 GHz.
NooElec TV28T From the research I have done, I have found that the NooElec TV28T dongle provides an approximate tuning range of 25MHz-1700MHz for the SDR. Â It has been demonstrated to be compatible with most SDR software, including SDR#. Â You can pick up FM radio butÂ Â don’t expect to pick up long-wave or AM broadcasts since their spectrum lies below 25MHz.Â You can listen to the 12m 10m 6m 2m 1.25m 70cm 33cm and 23cm ham band, as well as CB, Marine VHF, RC Band, FRS, GMRS, and Airband (Aviation).

The dongle will not provide the desired SDR function out of the box. Â It must first be configured (aka hacked) toÂ streamÂ the I/Q samples to the USB output. Â This is whereÂ Antii Palosaari’s discovery comes into play. Â The wiki’sÂ rtlsdr.orgÂ andÂ OsmoSDR areÂ good sources forÂ disparate information concerning RTL2832UÂ based SDR, typically called RTL-SDR. Â For my purposes, I wanted to get somethingÂ initiallyÂ working on my PC (Linux OS) but ultimately I wanted to have the dongle attached to a Raspberry Pi (RPi) and have the RPi be a server or archive of I/Q samples (sort of aÂ intelligentÂ wide bandÂ scanner as done inÂ Raspberry Pi and DVB-T receiversÂ and hereÂ Raspberry Pi as Remote Server for RTL2832u SDRÂ and hereÂ SDR with Raspberry Pi and DVB-T receivers) that could be processed by my PC. Â Therefore, the first step is to get the dongle and a good SDR processor working on my PC.

BuildingÂ rtl-sdr Library and Capture Tools

The Â OsmoSDR wiki has some good instructions on how to build the rtl-sdr software. IÂ basicallyÂ followed the wiki’s instructions but I had to first install cmake (sudo apt-get install cmake) and libusb (sudo apt-get install libusb-1.0-0-dev) to get a successful make. Â I then using the following commands:

cd ~/src
git clone git://git.osmocom.org/rtl-sdr.git
cd rtl-sdr/
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ../
make
sudo make install
sudo ldconfig
cmake ../ -DINSTALL_UDEV_RULES=ON

TheÂ result is source code placed in ~/src/rtl-sdr/build/src and theÂ executablesÂ are placed inÂ /usr/local/bin:Â rtl_adsb,Â rtl_eeprom,Â rtl_fm,Â rtl_sdr,Â rtl_tcp,Â rtl_test. Â The documentation for these utilities is nearly non-existent. Â The only documentation I could fine is for theÂ rtl_fm, a posting calledÂ Rtl_fm Guide:Â The long lost documentation. Â If you use the command line option --help, you will get someÂ descriptionÂ for each of the tools (see the very end of this post for some screen captures). Â Here is a shortÂ descriptionÂ and some example usages:

    • rtl_sdr - This is an I/Q recorder for RTL2832 based DVB-T receivers.Â To send 10 samples to stdout, and sampled at 1.8Ms/s with frequency tuned to 392MHz: rtl_sdr -s1.8e6 -f392e6 -n10 -.
    • rtl_test -Â Bench-markingÂ tool for RTL2832 based DVB-T receivers. Â The -t option only works forÂ Elonics E4000 tuners (Therefore, on non-E4000 tuners, you can not test for the tuning range). Â To check the possible tuning range:Â rtl_test -t. Â To check the maximumÂ sample-rateÂ possible on your machine (change the rate down until no sample loss occurs):Â rtl_test -s 2.5e6
    • rtl_fm - AÂ simple narrow band FM demodulator for RTL2832 based DVB-T receivers. Â Rtl_fm is a general purpose analog demodulator. It can handle FM, AM and SSB. It can scan more than a hundred frequencies a second. Make sureÂ rtl_fmÂ and the player are both set to use the same data rate. Â Tune into a local FM radio station : rtl_fm -W -f 99.5M | play -r 32k -t raw -e signed-integer -b 16 -c 1 -V1 -
    • rtl_tcp -Â Â An I/Q sample server for RTL2832 based DVB-T receivers. Â I/Q samples are streamed to a specified IP address and port.
    • rtl_adsb - AÂ simple Automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B)Â decoder. Â ADS-B is a surveillance technology for tracking aircraft as part of the Next Generation Air Transportation System (NextGen).
    • rtl_eeprom - An EEPROM programming tool for RTL2832 based DVB-T receivers.

First Run of the Dongle

The first thing to do is to plug in the dongle and run the test rtl_test -t. Â It gave me an errorÂ statementÂ expressing “installing the udev rules file rtl-sdr.rules”. Â The site “rtl-sdr on Ubuntu” provides some instructions on how to fix this. Â The command lsusb | grep Realtek gives me the information I need to create theÂ followingÂ entryÂ intoÂ /etc/udev/rules.d:

SUBSYSTEM=="usb", ATTRS{idVendor}=="0bda", ATTRS{idProduct}=="2838", GROUP="adm", MODE="0666", SYMLINK+="rtl_sdr"

After another try, I got a successful test. Â Next, I sent ten I/O samples to stdout and then tuned into a local FM radio station using these commands:

rtl_sdr -s1.8e6 -f392e6 -n10 - rtl_fm -W -f 99.5M | play -r 32k -t raw -e signed-integer -b 16 -c 1 -V1 -

Getting SDR# Running in Linux (didn’t work)

The Â rtlsdr.orgÂ wiki has some instructions on how to get SDR# working within Linux. Â Also, theÂ SDR# home pageÂ has a link calledÂ One shot install script for Linux. Both these sites require you to build the software from source code. Mono isÂ able to run Microsoft .NET applications in Linux. Â I attempted this and got errors that I could not figure out (I’m not a MS Windows developer type and I’m not interested becoming one!).

Given this, I chose aÂ differentÂ path. I found another posting that claim to get SDR# running in Linux.Â In this case, onlyÂ executableÂ will be loaded, not source code that needs to be compiled. You can download SDR#Â executableÂ from this posting. Â You’llÂ also need to install mono and PortAudio. Â Here is how I did it:

sudo apt-get install mono-complete monodevelop
sudo apt-get install libportaudio2
cd ~/src
mkdir sdrsharp
cd sdrsharp

Within ~/src/sdrsharp, install the downloaded SDR# zip file and unzip it.

cd sdr-nightly
ln -s /usr/local/lib/librtlsdr.so librtlsdr.dll
ln -s /usr/lib/i386-linux-gnu/libportaudio.so.2 libportaudio.so

Note, for the above link, you may need to useÂ locate libportaudio.so.2 to find the PortAudioÂ library.

To test things out, I ran the application using mono sdrsharp.exe and got a core dump. Â IÂ attempted this again using the stable version of SDR# instead of the nightly build and got the same results.Â Â After the typicalÂ thrashingÂ about, I found a bug report for this problem. Â Also see “SDR Software â Good, bad and very ugly“. Â Also, there seems to be some sort of dispute between SDR# and a new group calling itself Open SDR#. Â I’m not sure, but what appears to be at the heart of this is the level of support of SDR# within Linux. Â All this is disappointing since SDR# is a very popular tool and I wish I could find away to make use of it within Linux.

The next logical SDR tool to try would be the Linux-based Gqrx SDR receiver, but in this case, it is dependent on GNU Radio. Â I’m attempting to delay myÂ conquestÂ of GNU Radio until I do some experimenting with the dongle. Â So lets turn ourÂ attentionÂ to a much simpler tool.

GettingÂ RTL-SDR Scanner Running

RTLSDR ScannerÂ is a simpleÂ frequency scanning GUI using the OsmoSDR rtl-sdr library. Â I more or less followed the installation instructionsÂ but they are confusing/out-of-date and you’ll needed to do some adjustments. Â TheÂ OsmoSDRÂ rtlsdr library hasÂ alreadyÂ been installed earlier in the text, so its not listed here. Â To get the required files for RTLSDR Scanner:

sudo apt-get install python python-wxgtk2.8 python-matplotlib python-numpy
cd ~/src
git clone git://github.com/roger-/pyrtlsdr.git
cd pyrtlsdr
sudo setup.py
cd ~/src
git clone git://github.com/EarToEarOak/RTLSDR-Scanner.git

With this, I found I could run ~/src/pyrtlsdr/demo_waterfall.py. Â Make sure to read the comments in the file toÂ understandÂ how to change the center frequency,Â gain, etc. Â The image below is demo_waterfall.py tuned to the amateur radio 6 meters band. Â The image is called aÂ spectrogramÂ (sometimes call spectral waterfall)Â is a dynamic, visual representation of the spectrum of frequencies in the RF signal. Â Blue is low signalÂ strength,Â whereÂ yellow, and red are higher strengths.

To get ~/src/RTLSDR-Scanner/src/rtlsdr_scan.py to work, I had to do some coping of files as shown below:

cp ~/src/pyrtlsdr/rtlsdr/rtlsdr.py Â ~/src/RTLSDR-Scanner/src/rtlsdr.py
cp ~/src/pyrtlsdr/rtlsdr/librtlsdr.py Â ~/src/RTLSDR-Scanner/src/librtlsdr.py

The image below is fromÂ rtlsdr_scan.py, againÂ tuned to the amateur radio 6 meters band. Â Here again you see the signal strength of the individual amateurÂ radios as vertical spikes. So we now have auditory and visual proof the dongle is doing its job. Now its on to GNU Radio!

Command-Line Options for RTLSDR Capture Tools

For reference purposes, below are screen shots of the RTLSDR capture tool’s command line options.

rtl_test -s  rtl_test

rtl_tcp  rtl_sdr

rtl_adsb  rtl_fm
