item.title: Building My Linux Box...The Plan
item.description:
I concluded it was time to retire my current PC (aÂ Dell Dimension XPS 400, Intel Pentium D 820, 2.8GHz w/Dual Core Technology, 2G of memory, purchased in January 2006 for Â ~ $2,500) and replace it with something better, aka faster. Â It's performing poorly, but most of all, I want to do some experimenting with iPython &Â matplotlib, as well as, GNU Radio & digital signal processing. Â To do this justice, I need a faster box and ideally loaded with Linux and X Windows.

I also think its time for me to build my own box, instead of purchase it already packaged and assembled. Â TheyÂ say you get more for your dollar, or at least you can invest the same money into things that will make a better system (instead of some more crappy speakers, mice, keyboards, etc.). Â Given I'm building it, I want to pay special attention to getting theÂ performanceÂ up. Â I don't need the top of the line CPU (I don't believe you getÂ sufficientÂ valueÂ for your money), but I would invest in improving the predominateÂ enemyÂ of computerÂ performance,Â that is I/O. Â Also, I want the graphics to be fast and smooth. Â The work on matplotlib and signal processing is likely to be graphically intensive. Â I'm not going to be playing games on the system, but I'm going to keep an eye on the gaming communities hardwareÂ preferences.Â  Â I'm willing to go with a good (but not super, andÂ thereforeÂ expensive) graphics board.

A fancy sound system isn't a priority for me. Â While my interest in GNU Radio & digital signal processing may have some use for a good sound system, I think I could live with the integrated sound system that will come on theÂ motherboard. Â LikeÂ graphics, if Â it proves unacceptable, I'll make the investment on anotherÂ occasion.

Since I'm buyingÂ componentsÂ andÂ assemblingÂ it, I want to do some cherry picking. Â When a vendor sells you an assembled box, they are often using cheaper / less functionalÂ componentsÂ to save them cost. Â I'm picking an Intel Core i5 CPU (I believe it has the best value for me). Â Also, I'm going to get a -K Series Intel CPU and motherboard designed for overclocking and provide optimal performance for gamers and high-power users. Â While I'm not doing gaming, I like the option to tuning the hardware and I have found the -K Series to be onlyÂ slightlyÂ more expensive. Â For a small amount of additional cash, I get some cool capabilities.

To get the better I/O that I want, I'm going to purchase one solid-state drive (SSD)Â from which I plan to boot Linux. Â SSD's are very much more expensive byte-for-byte when compared to a standard hardÂ driveÂ but boy they can fly! Â Faster CPU and faster drives are my most valuable investment. Â With the Â financialÂ investment in the SSD, I'm not going to purchase new hard drives but reuse the ones I have in myÂ currentÂ PC (I'll need them since the SSD I can budget for will not be large). Â They are newer then the original Dell box, andÂ besidesÂ  the hard drive has over 6 years of stuff on it, including a MS WindowsÂ environmentÂ that I have grown dependent on. Â That brings me to the next point.

I want to dual boot the system with both MS Windows and Linux. Â The Linux will be on the SSD, and it is here that I plan to spend much of my time. Â I want to pick a Linux distribution that is well supported, popular, and a good graphic desktopÂ environment.Â  Â I grew up on the Linux command lineÂ (then it was Unix) and I feel at home there, but I would like toÂ tryÂ out the X Windows desktop.Â  If at allÂ possibleÂ  I want the MS Windows to boot from my current hard drive. Â I don't want to have to reload software or copy an image ... you never can get it to be the same again. Â If I must, I'll make the MS windows drive theÂ defaultÂ boot as it is now (and Microsoft seems to insist on being default). Â If I can do this, moving into my new PC will be painless.

With my objectives andÂ prioritiesÂ fully articulated, lets explore what I intend to build.

Central Processing Unit (CPU)

For my CPU I have picked theÂ Intel Core i5-3570K Ivy Bridge 3.4GHz (3.8GHz Turbo Boost and 6M Cache) LGA 1155 77W Quad-Core Desktop Processor which includes Virtualization Technology (VT-x),Â and Intel HD Graphics 4000. Â What a mouth full .... here is what this all means:
    • Intel Core -Â Intel Core (sometimesÂ refereedÂ to as Core 2) is a brand name that Intel uses for various mid-range to high-end consumer and business microprocessors. In general, processors sold as Core are more powerful variants of the same processors marketed as entry-level Celeron and Pentium. Similarly, identical or more capable versions of Core processors are also sold as Xeon processors for the server and workstation market.
    • i5-3570K - The very first question after you concluded that your going with the Intel Core line, isÂ Core i3 vs. i5 vs. i7 â Which one is right for me? Â Â I'm driven to the i5 since the current Intel Core i5 models are generally considered the best price/performance choice for a gaming system and the i7Â Â do NOT have built-in graphics capability (this would force me to buy a graphics card).Â Why K versions you ask? Well, the default Ivy Bridge processors are much harder to overclock, where the K series are unlocked and come with tools for overclocking. Â This processor has overclocked test results running at a stable 4.7GHz.
    • Ivy Bridge -Â Â Ivy Bridge is the latestÂ generationÂ of processors within theÂ Intel Tick-Tock Development Model. Â Â Intel introduced its Sandy Bridge desktop and laptop processors at the start of 2011 as there new micro-architecture ...the tock. Â Intel introducedÂ Ivy Bridge in April 2012 new processor technology ... the tick. Â There is a school of thought that says you shouldn't buy the last generation CPU because you can get more value (aka performance/dollar) from the previousÂ generation. Â But the prices I have seen and the comparative reviews have given me theÂ courageÂ to go with the latest generation. Â Also check out this review with aÂ descriptionÂ of Ivy Bridge.
    • Turbo Boost -Â This feature increases performance of both multi-threaded and single-threaded workloads. Â Intel Turbo Boost Technology 2.0 allows the processor core to opportunistically and automatically run faster than its rated operating frequency/graphic render clock if it is operating below power, temperature, and current limits. It can boost theÂ frequency upÂ to 3.8GHz.
    • 6M Cache - This refers toÂ cache used by the central processing unit of a computer to reduce the average time to access memory. The cache is a smaller, faster memory which stores copies of the data from the most frequently used main memory locations. Â It comes it three types: L1, L2, and L3.Â L1 cache (sometimes called primary cashe) is the fastest cache and it usually comes within theÂ processor chipÂ itself. Â L2 cache comes between L1 and RAM (processor-L1-L2-RAM) and is bigger than the primary cache. The L1 and L2 cache is per core but theÂ last-level cache (L3), is shared among all cores and sometimes call Smart Cache since cache can be dynamically assigned to a core as it needs it. The "6M" refers to the number of bytes of data that the L3 cache can hold.
    • LGA 1155 -Â LGA 1155, also called Socket H2, is an Intel microprocessor compatible 1155 pin socket which supports Intel Sandy Bridge and Ivy Bridge microprocessors.
    • 77W -Â This is the Â Thermal Design Power (TDP) is the maximum power consumed by the CPU under normal / regular use. In other words, the TDP is the max power a device will dissipate when running real applications. Whatâs more the TDP is given for graphics card default clocks. Â TDP is a manufacturerâs data, and thanks to this information, CPUcooler manufactures can size their CPU coolers.
    • Quad-Core Desktop Processor -Â This is a multi-core processor (in fact a quad or 4 core) Â computing component with four independent actual central processing units (called "cores"). Â Intel manufacturers the four cores onto a single integrated circuit die (known as a chip multiprocessor or CMP), or onto multiple dies in a single chip package. Â The proximity of multiple CPU cores on the same die allows it to operation at a much higher clock-rate than is possible if the signals have to travel off-chip.
    • Virtualization Technology - VT-xÂ Â (i.e. x86 virtualization or Vanderpool) is the facility that allows multiple operating systems to simultaneously share x86 processor resources in a safe and efficient manner, a facility generically known as hardware virtualization. With virtualization, you can have several operating systems running in parallel, each one with several programs running. Â Each operating system runs on a "virtual machine", i.e. each operating system thinks it is running on a completely independent computer. Note that on the Intel Core technology, the virtual machines are notÂ assignedÂ specific CPUs among the multiple CPUs but are shared by all.
    • Intel HD Graphics 4000 -Â Before the introduction of Intel HD Graphics, Intel integrated graphics were built into the motherboard's northbridge. Â HD Graphics 4000 is Intel's 3rd generation of thisÂ integratedÂ GPU technology. Â The HD 4000 was completely redesigned and offers many improvement. The IPC (instructions per clock) can therefore be even 2x as fast Â and overall up to 60% more performance should be possible.
One highly desirable feature missing from the Intel i5 line isÂ Hyper-Threading Technology. Â Hyper-Threading (HT) is a means for improving processor performance by supporting the execution of multiple threads (two is the current limit) on the same processor at once: the threads share the various on-chip execution units. Â HT is available on the i7 line of processors but I just can't justify the cost of thisÂ additionalÂ functionality.

Motherboard (Mobo)

I need to match the CPU to a -K Series motherboard and I picked the Intel Desktop Board DZ77GA-70KÂ withÂ Intel Z77 Express Chipset familyÂ which includes Intel High Definition Audio. The Intel high-definition audio chip allows you to use your computer to send digital audio signals to speakers, headphones, telephones and other audio equipment. Early computer audio systems could only produce simple stereo sound reproduction. The Intel HD audio system supports surround sound up to Dolby 7.1. Â It supports the Â usual 32GB of RAM,Â Smart Response Technology,Â Smart Connect Technology,Â Intel Rapid Storage Technology (Intel RST) for RAID 0, 1, 5, and 10. The "GA" in the motherboard's name means that it contains Bluetooth/WiFi and the a front panel USB 3.0 moduleÂ Â ("GAL" means it has noÂ Bluetooth/WiFi). The board supports Intel's Fast Boot TechnologyÂ which can dramatically reduce the time to boot the system. Support for high end graphics boards. It has eight Â USB 3.0Â ports (4 external/4 header), tenÂ USB 2.0Â ports (4 external (2 Hi-Current/Fast Charging) / 6 internal), four Serial ATA 6.0 Gb/s ports, one eSATA 6.0 Gb/s, fourÂ Serial ATAÂ 3.0 Gb/s ports and many other features.

The Mobo comes with theÂ Intel Visual BIOSÂ graphical interface and animated controls, which allow you to configure settings faster and take full advantage of your Intel -K processors.Â The Visual BIOS uses the Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) which defines a software interface between an operating system and Mobo firmware. UEFI is meant to replace the Basic Input/Output System (BIOS) firmware interface, present in all IBM PC-compatible personal computers.

The form factor for this Mobo is ATX. Â ATX (Advanced Technology eXtended) is a motherboard form factor specification developed by Intel in 1995 to improve on previous de facto standards like the AT form factor. Â There areÂ different form factor of motherboards including microATX, Standard ATX and XL-ATX. Â This is important to keep in mind when picking a case.

The selling feature for me was that its an Intel product (motherboards are new to me and I need the emotional support), seems easy to setup, it has gottenÂ reasonableÂ reviewsÂ (and here is another), and reasonable price. Â It isn't most feature full Mobo nor what a die-hardÂ overclockerÂ would buy but it seems a solid, stable product that will not give me any troubles or support problems and willÂ performÂ well.

Memory (RAM)

I'm going with 8GB of RAM in an effort to assure good I/O and 12GB or 16GB just seems like more than I will need. Â ThatÂ amountÂ of memory seemsÂ sufficientÂ for you average gamerÂ and should work for me. Â And the reviews I have seen also claim they haveÂ successivelyÂ overclocked this memory. According to the September 2011 Steam hardware survey, 4GB of RAM is currently the most popular configuration among gaming PCs. This may be sufficient for a light home user, however, many power users and enthusiasts find 4GB to be insufficient. Many recommend at least 6GB for any enthusiast PC, especially in light of the relatively

I also want to keep open the option to do some overclocking, so I need to considerÂ memory based on Intel's Â Extreme Memory Profile (XMP). Â I also want a memory provider with a solidÂ reparation. Â TheÂ Intel Core i5-3570K processor requiresÂ DDR3-1333/1600 memory. Â With all this in mind, I choose theÂ 8GB (2X4 GB) Corsair Vengeance Blue, 9-9-9-24, 1.5VÂ Â PC3-12800 1600MHz DDR3 240-Pin SDRAM Dual Channel Memory. Â Â They are not top of the line memory but seem a good fit for my needs and have gotten solid reviews.

DDR3 or DDR3 SDRAM, an abbreviation for double data rate type three synchronous dynamic random access memory, is a modern kind of dynamic random access memory (DRAM) with a high bandwidth interface, and has been in use since 2007. Â The primary benefit of DDR3 Â over its immediate predecessor (i.e. DDR2), is its ability to transfer data at twice the rate (eight times the speed of its internal memory arrays), enabling higher bandwidth or peak data rates.Â The next generation, Â DDR4 expected to be released to the market sometime in 2013. Â Its primary benefits compared to DDR3 is the higher range of clock frequencies (200MHz vs 166MHz) and data transfer rates (400MT/s vs 333MT/s).

DDR3 memory is classified according to the maximum speed at which it can work, as well as their timings. Timing are numbers such as 3-4-4-8, 5-5-5-15, 7-7-7-21, 9-9-9-24 where lower is better. Memory speed is specified via a number like this: DDR3-xxx / PC3-yyy or DDR3-xxx/yyy. The xxx number indicates the maximum clock speed that the memory chip supports. Therefore, DDR3-1333 can work up to 1,333MHz. Note this isn't the real clock speed but twice that speed. So the real clock speed of DDR3-1333 is 666MHz.Â The yyy indicates the maximum transfer rate that the memory can reach. So memory labeled as DDR3-1333/10664 has a transfer rate of 10,664MB/s or 21,328 MB/s if they are running under dual channel mode. Most current boards have dual with the Intel socket 1336 has triple channel.

The memory timings x-x-x-x indicates the number of clock cycles that it takes for the memory to perform something. The smaller the number, the faster the memory. These set of four numerical parameters are called CL, tRCD, tRP, and tRAS. Sometimes there a fifth value which is voltage. Check out Understanding RAM Timings for more information.

Memory is sold in âkitsâ which are simply multiple single, similar (identical as possible) RAM modules packaged together. The intention is for them to be used in motherboards that have dual and triple (etc.) RAM channel capabilities.

Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)

I'm going to try and live with the on-boardÂ graphics processing unit (GPU)Â integrated with the CPU and invest that money elsewhere. Â  TheÂ reviews of Â Intel's newestÂ integrated GPUÂ that comes with the i5-3570K (HD Graphics 4000Â orÂ HD 4000)Â have beenÂ favorable (also seeÂ this). Â  This is theÂ Â third and latest generation of HD GraphicsÂ (now with 16 execution units) and appears to be a realÂ contenderÂ to low end graphics cards.Â  If it proves less than acceptable, I'm invest in a graphics board another day.

Sound Card

Here again, I'm not buying a separate card but using theÂ Intel High Definition AudioÂ integrated into the motherboard. Â Frankly, I'm not sure if this will limit myÂ GNU Radio & digital signal processing objectives but I'll take the risk. Â If I'm unhappy for any reason, I'll buy myself a sound board.

Solid State Drive (SSD)

I haveÂ chosenÂ theÂ Samsung Electronics 840 Pro Series 2.5-Inch 128GB SATA 6GB/s for my Solid State Drive (SSD). Â Samsung has a greatÂ repatriationÂ in thisÂ spaceÂ and it has gotten solid reviews.

What most people who use SSDs do (and what I plan to do) is to buy one large enough to hold the OS and applications, and also buy a hard drive to hold the rest of your documents, photos, videos, etc. That's a good compromise which puts the most performance-critical files on the fastest drive and has the cheapest cost-per-byte for yourÂ voluminousÂ data files which typically have much lower performance requirements. Â But keep in mind that as soon as the amount of data written reaches the stated capacity of the device, the write bandwidth immediately drops.Â  In fact, write bandwidth reduced by up to 70-80% once fully loaded with data and continued to operate under those conditions.Â  Therefore, donât fill the SSD drive.

Also, one of the most publicized downsides of SSDs is that they have a limited number of writes before they wear outâhowever, with most newer SSDs, this isn't actually a problem. Most modern SSDs will become outdated before they die, and you'll probably have upgraded by then, so there's not really a huge need to worry about writing to the drive too many times.

Because of the high speed of the SSD, your going to want to use the 6GB/s SATA ports on the motherboard. Â The standard 3GB/s SATA ports don't have the throughput, never the less, studies show the SSD still give you benefits.

Power Supply Unit (PSU)

I choose the popular Â Corsair TX650 650-Watt Power SupplyÂ as my PSU. Most computers only consume around 150W, and even a high end computer might consume maybe 200W. That's why most OEM computer manufacturers put small 250-350W PSUs in their systems. If you look at online reviews of highly overclocked systems with multiple video cards (SLI/Crossfire) they consume at most about 500-600W. Â  I don't believe I'll ever approach these levels so this PSU will give me much head room. Â The review I have read seem to claim thatÂ he best way to take advantage of the TX650W's quiet qualities is Â to ensure that the PSU intake air does not exceed 30Â°C often, nor demand more than ~350W DC output. Â I believe myÂ usageÂ will fit in this sweat spot.

Networking

Networking capabilities are built into the motherboard. Â The Mobo comes withÂ two Gigabit (10/100/1000 Mb/s) LAN subsystems using the Intel 82579V Gigabit Ethernet Controller. It also has aÂ Bluetooth 2.1 & WiFi 802.11b/g/n module. There appears to have been some troubles with WiFi and Bluetooth module for DZ77GA-70K in 2012, but it has been reported to Intel and hopefully this has been worked out by now. Â I'll have to make sure I update the firmware on the board when I get it.

CD-ROM / DVD Drive / Hard Drives

I'm not going to worry about this now. Â I anticipate loading all my software / data from the Web orÂ transferringÂ from my existing hard drives. Â Also, I'll reuse my existing hard drives in this box.

Cooler Case

TheÂ Intel Core i5-3570K comes with a stock cooler. Â If do over clock the CPU, I'mÂ likelyÂ to need a better cooler, but this is fine for now. Picking a case has been the hardest thing for me to select. Â I guess this is because its not as much a technical decision but an aesthetic choice. Â I have narrowed my choose to theÂ Cooler Master HAF 912 - Mid Tower Computer Case with High Airflow Design (19.5 x 9.1 x 18.9 inches ; 17.8 pounds). Â It has gotten good reviews with the mainÂ complaintÂ being that it needs more fans (much room for more installation but only two are provided). Â The front panel comes with the older USB 2.0 ports but the Mobo comes with a USB 3.0 panel that could be install if desired. Â The case isn't expensive but still has a sharp look and seems veryÂ versatileÂ in its use and cooling.

Monitor

The Dell LCD monitor I presently have dates back to 2006 and isn'tÂ equippedÂ with HDMI, which is the onlyÂ way to interface with the Mobo. Â I presently use my monitor via itsÂ Digital Video Interface Digital (DVI-D), but it also has Video Graphics Array (VGA) and Composite Video inputs. Â So if I wish to continue to use the monitor, I'll need aÂ converterÂ of some type. Â I found that the DVI-D to HDMI can be done via an inexpensive cable, so that is the way I'm going. Â I specifically need a HDMI Type A to DVI-D Dual Link Male to MaleÂ cable.

Operating System (OS)

I plan toÂ installÂ Ubuntu Linux on the SSD drive. Â Picking the Linux distribution was nearly as hard as picking the case. Â I choose Ubuntu because of its popularity and I wanted toÂ experienceÂ its desktopÂ environment once again, GNOME. Â I used GNOME many years ago when it was very young, I saw potential, and I would like to see how it has grown. I plan to spend the vast majority of my time within Xterm at the commandÂ prompt, but I also want to get familiarÂ with Ubuntu/GNOME. Â I'll also do most of my systemsÂ administrationÂ at the command prompt, but again, getting familiarityÂ with Ubuntu would be good to know.

How do I plan to installing Ubuntu, given that I will not have a OS already installed and I will not have a CD-ROM/DVD? Â Ubuntu does have an ability to be installed via an USB stick.

I'm not going toÂ abandonÂ MS Windows. Â I have many tools that I use in Windows and its notÂ practicalÂ to justÂ abandonÂ them for something else, at least not right now. Â I would like to dual boot the system with Linux and MS Windows. Â Ideally, I'll keep my old Windows image on myÂ currentÂ PC's hard drive, put that drive in my new system, and have the hard drive be my second OS on the bootloader's chain of operating systems. Â I know this could be done if I choose toÂ re-installÂ MS Windows and all my applications but I don't know the challenges I'll face given I'm using an establish image .... it will be a learningÂ opportunity!

If I'm forces to do a re-install of MS Windows, I might usÂ Oracle VM VirtualBox, which is a x86 virtualization software package. VirtualBox can be installed on an existing host operating system as an application; this host application allows additional guest operating systems, each known as a Guest OS, to be loaded and run, each with its own virtual environment. Â The typical way of installing a guest operating system is to install it from the ground up. In general, you donât see VirtualBox running a guest operating system from an existing drive or partition. Â Never the less, a search of the Web does show evidence that people have made it work this way (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7).

The last, and least desirable approach (for my needs) is to use Windows applications is viaÂ Wine. Â Wine (originally an acronym for "Wine Is Not an Emulator") is a compatibility layer capable of running Windows applications on Linux. Instead of simulating internal Windows logic like a virtual machine or emulator, Wine translates Windows API calls into Linux calls on-the-fly, eliminating the performance and memory penalties of other methods and allowing you to cleanly integrate Windows applications into your desktop. Â Since it doesn't create a virtual machine programs perform faster than in a VM. Â However, you'll need to test it with your application since it doesn't support all programs. Â Also, youâre not running MS Windows, just the MS Windows compatible applications. Â This is fine if your interest in running Excel standalone, but you canât perform anything that requires the MS operating system.

Boot Loader

A boot loader is the first software program that runs when a computer starts. It is responsible for loading and transferring control to the operating system kernel software. The kernel, in turn, initializes the rest of the operating system.Â  GRUB (GRand Unified Bootloader) is a boot loader package developed to support multiple operating systems and allow the user to select among them during boot-up. Â GRUB is often the default boot loader for Linux and is preferred to MS Windows since it makes up for numerous deficiencies while providing full-featured command line and graphical interfaces. Â GRUBÂ is the default boot loaderÂ for Ubuntu, making it an easy choose. Â GRUB is powerful and complex so check outÂ How I configured grub as the default bootloader on a UEFI Boot systems.

What does it Cost

Now that I have a plan, what will all this cost? Â I estimate it will be $765, less than one-third the cost of my present system. Â Granted I’ll be reusing the monitor, key board, mouse, and some drives but this is aÂ substantialÂ priceÂ differenceÂ for what will be a much more capable machine.

To see what I finally implemented, check outÂ Building My Linux Box…The Implementation.

item.title: A Better Mobile Display for the Raspberry Pi
item.description:
As IÂ describedÂ in an earlier post, I run my Raspberry Pi (RPi) as a headless system, using Cygwin/X‘s xterm for command lineÂ interactionÂ with the RPi,Â with my PC being my X server to support any X Window applications. Â I can move files between the PC and the RPi via myÂ pseudo-Dropbox. Â I really recommend thisÂ configurationÂ and its working perfectly for me.

This configuration gives me a great deal of utility but no mobility …. I’m still tied to my desktop PC. Â Maybe I should consider replacing the desktop PC with a laptop but I don’t want to spend the money. Â I have seen someÂ small, Â inexpensive keyboards and displays that could be connected directly to the RPi, and you could cobble together a mobile unit, or the more elegantÂ Kindle version, but this still doesn’t give me the mobility look & feel I would like.

iPad to the rescue (assuming you have one ….)! Â  I found a great app call iSSHÂ by Zingersoft. Â Its claims that it is a “comprehensive VT100, VT102, VT220, ANSI, xterm, and xterm-color terminal emulator over SSH and telnet, integrated with a tunneled X server, RDP and VNC client.Â ” Â  I installed it, configured it quickly, and got Â a terminal connection to the RPi without reading the documentation …. Impressive since successfully configuringÂ ssh, Xserver, etc. can beÂ challenging sometimes. Â (Note: The easy of this was largely due to setting up RPiÂ environmentÂ properly in the first place. See the earlier post). Â To top it off, iSSH has a slick look & feel.

Configuring iSSH

Zingersoft’sÂ documentation on configuring iSSH isÂ easyÂ to follow and requires just a few steps. Â I had no problem getting an terminal session working to the RPi but I did have problems with graphics programs (i.e. X Window client programs). Â It appears that iSSH’s terminal isn’t really xterm but a terminal emulationÂ (secured via ssh). Â The iSSH terminal doesn’t use the X server. Â In fact, while in theÂ terminalÂ session, Â to see the X serverÂ displayÂ (i.e. to see graphics applications rendered via the RPi X client) you must hit the button at the top right of the iPad display.

Frankly, the fact that the X application didn’t work the first time wasn’t a big surprise to me. Â I have beenÂ strugglingÂ with getting my X Window configuration set up to work reliablyÂ for some time. Â What I was observing was that X would work fine for sometime but at some pointÂ I would get the error message “couldn’t connect to display”.

This error is veryÂ commonÂ and nearly every X user has seen some version of this before. Â I assume that the right way to solve this was to gain a deeper understanding of X Windows and discover its root cause . Â I did gain a deeper understanding of X Windows, but a solution to my problem never jumped out from the “official” materials I read. Â I found the solution when I happened upon the blog “X11 Display Forwarding Fails After Some Time“.

The root cause of my error message is the time out of the X Forwarding. Â I have been using the -X option when using ssh. Â This is the more secure option for X Forwarding, but comes at a price, as shown below.

    • Using ssh -X, X forwarding is enabled in “Untrusted” mode, making use of various X security extensions, including a time-limited Xauth cookie.
    • Use ssh -Y to enable “Trusted” mode for X, which will enable complete access to your X server. There is no timeout for this option.
So my Display problem isn’t really an error, per say, but sshÂ timingÂ out on me. Â To fix this, I added the entry ForwardX11Timeout 596h into my ~/.ssh/config file on my PC. Â With this problem solved, I continued my journey into X.

MyÂ JourneyÂ to a Better Understanding of X

Using X Windows for the first time can be somewhat of a shock to someone familiar with other graphical environments, such as Microsoft Windows or Mac OS. Â X was designed from the beginning to be network-centric, and uses a âclient-serverâ model. In the X model, the âX serverâ runs on the computer that has the keyboard, monitor, and mouse attached. The server’s responsibility includes tasks such as managing the display, handling input from the keyboard and mouse, and other input or output devices (i.e., a âtabletâ can be used as an input device, and a video projector can be an output device, etc.). Each X application (such as xterm) is a âclientâ. A client sends messages to the server requesting things like âPlease draw a window at these coordinatesâ, and the server sends back messages such as âThe user just clicked on the OK buttonâ. These standardized set of messages make up the X Protocol.

The X server and the X clients commonly run on the same computer. However, it is perfectly possible to run the X server on a less powerful computer (e.g. in my case a PC or iPad), and run X applications (the clients) on a powerful machine that serves multiple X servers (or it can be a simple RPi, as in my case). In this scenario the communication between the X client and server takes place over the network (WiFi for my iPad), via the X Protocol. There is nothing in the protocol that forces the client and server machines to be running the same operating system, or even to be running on the same type of computer.

The Display

It is important to remember that the X server is the is the software program which manages the monitor, keyboard, and pointing device. In theÂ X window system, these three devices areÂ collectivelyÂ referredÂ to as the “display”.Â  Therefore, the X server serves displaying capabilities, via the display, to other programs, called X clients, that connect to Â the X server. Â All these connections are established via the X protocol.

The relationship between the X server and the display are tight, in that the X server is engineered to support aÂ specificÂ display (or set of displays). Â As a user of X, you don’t have any control over this relationship, only the software developer who created the server canÂ modifyÂ this relationship (generallyÂ speaking). Â On the other hand, as a user you have free hand in configuring the X protocol connection betweenÂ the X server and the X clients.

How do you establish a XÂ ProtocolÂ connection between any given server and a client? Â This is done via theÂ environment variable “DISPLAY”. Â AÂ LinuxÂ environment variable DISPLAY tells all its X clients what display they should use for their windows. Its value is set by default in ordinary circumstances, when you start an X server and run jobs locally. Alternatively, you can specify the display yourself. Â One reason to do this is when you want log into another system, and run a X client there, and but have the window displayed at your local terminal. Â That is, the DISPLAYÂ environmentÂ variable must point to your local terminal.

So the environment variable “DISPLAY” stores the address for X clients to connect to. These addresses are in the form:Â hostname:displaynumber.screennumber where

    • hostname is the name of the computer where the X server runs. An omitted hostname means the localhost.
    • displaynumber is a sequence number (usually 0). It can be varied if there are multiple displays connected to one computer.
    • screennumberÂ is the screen number. A display can actually have multiple screens. Usually there’s only one screen though where 0 is the default.
Setting the DISPLAY variable depends of your shell, but for theÂ Bourne, Bash or Korn shell, you could do the following to connect with the systems local display:

export DISPLAY=localhost:0.0

The remote server knows where it have to redirect the X network traffic via the definition of the DISPLAYÂ environment variableÂ which generally points to anÂ X Display serverÂ located on your local computer.

X Security

So you see, as the user, you have full control over where you wish to display the X client window. Â  So what prevents you from doing somethingÂ malicious,Â  like popping up window on someoneÂ elseÂ  terminal or read their key strokes? Â After all, all you really need is their host name. Â X servers have three ways of authenticating connections to it: the host list mechanism (xhost) and the magic cookie mechanism (xauth). Then there is ssh, that can forward X connections,Â providing a protected connection between client and server over a network using a secureÂ tunnelling protocol.

The xhost Command

The xhost program is used to add and delete host (computer) names or user names to the list of machines and users that are allowed to make connections to the X server. This provides a rudimentary form of privacy control and security. Â A typical use is as follows:Â Let’s call the computer you are sitting at the “local host” and the computer you want to connect to the “remote host”. You first use xhost to specify which computer you want to give permission to connect to the X server of the local host. Then you connect to the remote host using telnet. Next you set the DISPLAY variable on the remote host. You want to set this DISPLAY variable to the local host. Now when you start up a program on the remote host, its GUI will show up on the local host (not on the remote host).

For example, assume the IP address of the local host is 128.100.2.16 and the IP address of the remote host is 17.200.10.5.

On the local host, type the following at the command line:

xhost + 17.200.10.5

Log on to the remote host

telnet 17.200.10.5

On the remote host (through the telnet connection), instruct the remote host to display windows on the local host by typing:

export DISPLAY=128.100.2.16:0.0

Now when you type xterm on the remote host, you should see an xterm window on the local host. Â You should remove the remote host from your access control list as follows.

xhost - 17.200.10.5

Some additional xhost commands:

xhostList all the hosts that have access to the X server xhost + hostnameAdds hostname to X server access control list. xhost - hostnameRemoves hostname from X server access control list. xhost +Â Turns off access control (all remote hosts will have access to X server … generally a bad thing to do) xhost -Turns access control back on (all remote hosts blocked access to X server)

Xhost is a very insecure mechanism. It does not distinguish between different users on the remote host. Also, hostnames (addresses actually) can be spoofed. This is bad if you’re on an untrusted network.

The xauth Command

Xauth allows access to anyone who knows the right secret. Such a secret is called an authorization record, or a magic cookie. This authorization scheme is formally called MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1. Â The cookies for different displays are stored together in the fileÂ .XauthorityÂ in the user’s home directory (you can specify a different cookie file with the XAUTHORITY environment variable). Â TheÂ xauthÂ application is a utility for accessing theÂ .XauthorityÂ file.

On starting a session, the X server reads a cookie from the.XauthorityÂ file. After that, the server only allows connections from clients that know the same cookie (Note: When the cookie in .Xauthority changes, the server will not pick up the change.). Â If you want to use xauth, you must start the X server with theÂ -auth authfileÂ argument. Â  You can generate a magic cookie for theÂ .Xauthority file using the utility mcookie (typical usage: xauth add :0 . mcookie).

Now that you have started your X session on the server and have your cookie in .Xauthority, you will have to transfer the cookie to the client host. There are a few ways to do this. Â The most basic way is toÂ transfer the cookie manually by listing the magic cookie for your display with xauth list and injecting it into the remote hostsÂ .Xauthority via the xauth utility.

Xauth has a clear security advantage over xhost. You can limit access to specific users on specific computers and it does not suffer from spoofed addresses as xhost does.

X Over SSH

Even with the xhost and xauth methods, the Â the X protocol is transmitted over the network with no encryption. Â If you’re Â worried someone might snoop on your connections (and you should worry), use ssh. Â SSH, or the Secure Shell, allows secure (encryptedÂ andÂ authenticated) connections between any two devices running SSH. These connections may include terminal sessions, file transfers, TCP port forwarding, or X Window System forwarding. Â SSH supports a wide variety of encryption algorithms. It supports variousÂ MACÂ algorithms, and it can useÂ public-key cryptographyÂ for authentication or the traditional username/password.

SSH can do something called “X Forwarding” makes the communication secure by “tunneling” the X protocol over the SSH secure link. Â Forwarding is a type of interaction with another network application,Â throughÂ aÂ inter-mediator, in this case SSH. SSH intercepts a service request from some other program on one side of an SSH connection, sends it across the encrypted connection, and delivers it to the intended recipient on the other side. This process is mostly transparent to both sides of the connection: each believes it is talking directly to its partner and has no knowledge that forwarding is taking place. Â This is called tunneling sinceÂ X protocol is encapsulated within the a SSH protocol.

When setting up an SSH tunnel for X11, the Xauth key will automatically be copied to the remote system(in a munged form to reduce the risk of forgery) and the DISPLAY variable will be set.

To turn on X forwarding over ssh, use the command line switchÂ -XÂ or write the following in your local ssh configuration file:

Host remote.host.name ForwardX11 yes

The current version of SSH supports the X11 SECURITY extension, which provides two classes of clients: trusted clients, which can do anything with the display, and untrusted clients, which cannot inject synthetic events (mouse movement, keypresses) or read data from other windows (e.g., take screenshots). It should be possible to run almost all clients as untrusted, leaving the trusted category for screencapture and screencast programs, macro recorders, and other specialized utilities.

If you useÂ ssh -X remotemachineÂ the remote machine is treated as an untrusted client andÂ ssh -Y remotemachineÂ the remote machine is treated as trusted client. Â ’-X’ is supposedly the safe alternative to ‘-Y’. Â However, as a Cygwin/X maintainer says “this is widely considered to be not useful, because the Security extension uses an arbitrary and limited access control policy, which results in a lot of applications not working correctly and what is really a false sense of security”.

You can configuring SSH via the following files:

    • per-user configuration is inÂ ~/.ssh/config
    • system-wide client configuration is inÂ /etc/ssh/ssh_config
    • system-wide daemonÂ configurationÂ is inÂ /etc/ssh/sshd_config
The ssh server (sshd) at the remote end automatically setsÂ DISPLAYÂ to point to its end of the X forwarding tunnel. The remote tunnel end gets its own cookie; the remote ssh server generates it for you and puts it in~/.XauthorityÂ there. So, XÂ authorizationÂ with ssh is fully automatic.

X over SSH solves some of the problems inherent to classic X networking. For example, SSH can tunnel X traffic through firewalls and NAT, and the X configuration for the session is taken care of automatically. It will also handle compression for low-bandwidth links. Â Also, if you’re using X11 forwarding, you may want to consider settingÂ ForwardX11Trusted noÂ to guard against malicious clients.

The Window Manager

The X design philosophy is much like the Linux/UNIXÂ design philosophy, âtools, not policyâ. Â This philosophy extends to X not dictating what windows should look like on screen, how to move them around with the mouse, what keystrokes should be used to move between windows, what the title bars on each window should look like, etc. Â Instead, X delegates this responsibility to an application called a âWindow Managerâ.

There areÂ many window managersÂ available for X and each Â provides a different look and feel. Â Some of them support Â highlyÂ configurableÂ virtual desktops like,Â KDEÂ andÂ GNOME, some of them areÂ lightweightÂ desktop likeÂ LXDEÂ which comes with the RPi, or you can operate bare bones (like I am on my PC while using the RPi) and let MS Windows be your Window Manager viaÂ Cygwin/X.Â Â The iPad’s iSSH can run without a Window Manager. Â In effect, X server uses theÂ displayÂ as it sees fit and your unable to control where things loaded. iSSH does have a Window Manage your can use as an option calledÂ dwm. Â Its aÂ tiling window manager, which is aÂ reasonableÂ way to go given that your pointing device is your finger on the iPad.

X Display Manager

The X Display Manager (XDM) is an optional part of the X Window System that is used for login session management. Â XDM provides a graphical interface for choosing which display server to connect to, and entering authorization information such as a login & password. Â Like the LinuxÂ gettyÂ utility, it performs system logins to the display being connected to and then runs a session manager on behalf of the user (usually an X window manager). Â XDM then waits for this program to exit, signaling that the user is done and should be logged out of the display. At this point, XDM can display the login and display chooser screens for the next user to login.

In the small world of my RPi’s, a PC, and an iPad, I have no need for an XDM and don’t use one.

Enough of the XÂ JourneyÂ … Now in Conclusion

So what does the iSSH give me? I can now sit on the couch, watch TV, andÂ simultaneouslyÂ login into the RPi with full X Windows support. Â Some would call this Nirvana but I call it just VERY NICE. Â The iPad/iSSH combination isn’t the perfect userÂ experienceÂ but Zingersoft did a good job.

By the way …. the above iPad screen shot of the X Server display with a globe was rendered using the following code:

#!/usr/bin/env python

# Source: http://www.scipy.org/Cookbook/Matplotlib/Maps

from mpl_toolkits.basemap import Basemap
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

Use_NASA_blue_marble_image = False

# set up orthographic map projection with
# perspective of satellite looking down at 50N, 100W.
# use low resolution coastlines.
# don't plot features that are smaller than 1000 square km.
map = Basemap(projection='ortho', lat_0=50, lon_0=-100, resolution='l', area_thresh=1000.)

# draw coastlines, country boundaries, fill continents.
if Use_NASA_blue_marble_image:
    map.bluemarble()
else:
    map.drawcoastlines()
    map.drawcountries()
    map.fillcontinents(color='coral')

# draw the edge of the map projection region (the projection limb)
map.drawmapboundary()

# draw lat/lon grid lines every 30 degrees.
map.drawmeridians(np.arange(0, 360, 30))
map.drawparallels(np.arange(-90, 90, 30))

# lat/lon coordinates of five cities.
lats = [40.02, 32.73, 38.55, 48.25, 17.29]
lons = [-105.16, -117.16, -77.00, -114.21, -88.10]
cities = ['Boulder, CO', 'San Diego, CA', 'Washington, DC', 'Whitefish, MT', 'Belize City, Belize']

# compute the native map projection coordinates for cities.
x, y = map(lons, lats)

# plot filled circles at the locations of the cities.
map.plot(x, y, 'bo')

# plot the names of those five cities.
for name, xpt, ypt in zip(cities, x, y):
        plt.text(xpt + 50000, ypt + 50000, name)

# make up some data on a regular lat/lon grid.
nlats = 73
nlons = 145
delta = 2. * np.pi / (nlons - 1)
lats = (0.5 * np.pi - delta * np.indices((nlats, nlons))[0, :, :])
lons = (delta * np.indices((nlats, nlons))[1, :, :])
wave = 0.75 * (np.sin(2. * lats) ** 8 * np.cos(4. * lons))
mean = 0.5 * np.cos(2. * lats) * ((np.sin(2. * lats)) ** 2 + 2.)

# compute native map projection coordinates of lat/lon grid.
x, y = map(lons * 180. / np.pi, lats * 180. / np.pi)

# contour data over the map.
CS = map.contour(x, y, wave + mean, 15, linewidths=1.5)

plt.show()

item.title: The Simplest XBee Network
item.description:
As I continue myÂ investigationÂ of the XBee radio, I’m impressed by the functionality compressed into the the small package, but I have been frustrated by one fact. Â It has been a hard road to understand the device and to make it do something useful. Â There is a confusing mass of commands and options that can be used. Â To make things more difficult for me, it is my nature to study my subject at depth, and understand it well, before I commit myself to a project. Â The XBee radios are proving to be a deep subject. Â I have been struggling to get a simple 802.15.4 network up and working, at least one that isÂ sufficientlyÂ complex to be useful for my needs.

I stumbled into the realization that I don’t have to master 802.15.4 and a large set of XBee commands to make a very simple but potentially useful network. Â It’s a very basic observation about all radio devices like the XBee. Â You see, at its core the XBee radio is Â a modem. Â It encodes digital information, transmits its digits viaÂ electromagnetism, within a specificÂ frequencyÂ band, to beÂ receivedÂ by another XBee, and Â then converted back toÂ digitalÂ information. Â The use of packet data, the 802.15.4 protocol, and all the AT commands are layers on top of the XBee’s Â modem capability. Â The modem, the core communications sub-component, is a serial communications device with aÂ Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitter (UART) as examined in an earlier blog. Â So why not we just treat the XBee radio as a simple serial communication device? Â Drop the idea of packetizedÂ data and 802.15.4 protocol and just do rawÂ serialÂ communications.

While this simplification is seductive, it does come at a price. Data is packetized andÂ transmittedÂ using aÂ protocolÂ for very good reasons. Â In dataÂ transmissionÂ you must considerÂ theÂ fact that data could getÂ corrupted, you need to share the communication channel with others, Â data streams may be long (if not endless) and need to be properly sequenced, communications is main betweenÂ specificÂ devices as apposed to justÂ broadcasting, and many other concerns. Â You give up much of this by doing raw serialÂ communications but you gainÂ simplicity.

What I plan to do here is list some simple, proof of concept programs that I used to create a network with a Arduino and Raspberry Pi (RPi) using XBee radios. Â You could simply add additional devices, using the same code, and it will become a fully interconnected network (i.e. where every device can talk to every other devicesÂ directly). Â WhileÂ inferiorÂ to a 802.15.4 network on many levels, its quick to get operational and easy to debug. Â Also keep in mind that this is built on the XBee radio, Â but you could do this with most any radio which supports serial communications.

Architecture

I’ll be using a Arduino and a RPis for for my network, each with a XBee radio thought which they can communicate. I’ll establish terminal interface into each device so I can enter text for the device to transmit and the terminal will also show what messages where revived. All Â terminals will be within windows on my PC using PuTTY, Xterm, or the Arduino’s serial monitor screen.

Initializing the XBee Radios

First step is to make sure all the XBee radios that will be part of your network are properly configured. Â Specifically, you need to make sure the PAN ID and Channel ID of the XBee radio’s are identical. Â To accomplish this, I used the XBeeTerm.pyÂ utility IÂ posted in my earlier blog titledÂ Configuration Utilities for XBee Radios. Â I’m going to setup my network with two XBee radios (but you can use as many as you wish) and I used the configuration file below on both radios:

# To remove comments, white spaces, and blank lines, use the following:
#       sed '/^#/d; s/\([^$]\)#.*/\1/' Modem-Device.txt | sed 's/[ \t]*$//' > modemd.txt
# Run this script to configure the XBee radio using the following:
#       ./XBeeTerm.py modemd.txt
#
baudrate 9600       # (XBeeTerm command) set the baudrate used to comm. with the XBee
serial /dev/ttyUSB0 # (XBeeTerm command) serial device which has the XBee radio
+++             # (XBee command) enter AT command mode on the XBee
ATRE            # (XBee command) restore XBee to factory settings
ATID B000       # (XBee command) Set the PAN ID to eight byte hex (all XBee's must have this same value)
ATCH 0E         # (XBee command) set the Channel ID to a four byte hex (all XBee's must have same value)
ATPL 0          # (XBee command) power level at which the RF module transmits (0 lowest / 4 highest)
ATWR            # (XBee command) write all the changes to the XBee non-volatile memory
ATFR            # (XBee command) reboot XBee radio
exit            # (XBeeTerm command) exit python shell

Arduino Configuration

The sketch on theÂ ArduinoÂ is very simple. Called XBeeModem.ino and is listed blow:

/*
    The XBee devise should be connected to the Arduino Uno in the following way:
        XBee RX is connected to Arduino TX pin 3
        XBee TX is connected to Ardunio RX pin 2
        XBee +5V and Ground pins connect to the same on the Arduino
 */

#define RXPIN 2
#define TXPIN 3
#define BAUDRATE 9600

#include

SoftwareSerial XBeeSerial =  SoftwareSerial(RXPIN, TXPIN);

void setup()
{
    pinMode(13, OUTPUT);

    // Set the data rate for the hardware Serial port
    // and post a message stating so on the Arduino's Serial Monitor.
    Serial.begin(BAUDRATE);
    Serial.println("Arduino #1 up and running.");

    // Set the data rate for the SoftwareSerial port and
    // send a message out stating so via the XBee to the other devices.
    XBeeSerial.begin(BAUDRATE);
    XBeeSerial.println("Arduino #1 up and running.");
}

void loop()
{
    char c;

    // Read data arriving from the XBee and send to Arduino Serial Monitor.
    if (XBeeSerial.available()) {
        Serial.print((char)XBeeSerial.read());
    }

    // Capture data typed at the Arduino Serial Monitor, echo the data to the Serial Monitor,
    // and send that data via the XBee.
    if (Serial.available()) {
        c = (char)Serial.read();
        Serial.print(c);
        XBeeSerial.print(c);
    }

    delay(100);
}

Raspberry Pi Configuration

The Python program on the RPi is also very simple, except for one point. Â Linux I/O reads will block if there are no characters to read. Â You must “turn-off” blocking. Â The program is calledÂ XBeeModem.pyÂ and is listed blow:

Closing

It doesn’t get much simpler than this. With a little work, you might make something useful out of this technique but its very limited in the types of problems that it could handle. Never the less, it was a good diversion for me to clear my mind. Now back to the XBee’s core capabilites, the 802.15.4 protocol, and the other minutia!

item.title: Configuration Utilities for XBee Radios
item.description:
My ultimate aim is to wirelessly network several Arduino basedÂ platformsÂ with a centralized Raspberry PiÂ controller. There is much for me to learn to get this operational, not the least of which is the radio device I plan to use, the Xbee. Â To get up to speed on theÂ Xbee, I found the tutorials at Adafruit,Â Sparkfun, and ParallaxÂ helpful. Â  More detailed referencesÂ are listed at the end of this post, but the very first challenge is toÂ configureÂ the XBee radios for operation. Â This postÂ providesÂ insight on how this can be done, and my main mission, create a few simple utilities that make that job easy.

Xbee Radios

I purchased twoÂ XBeeÂ SeriesÂ 1 Module (FreescaleÂ 802.15.4 firmware) from Adafruit. Â These areÂ manufacturedÂ by Digi and are low-power module with wire antennaÂ Â (XB24-AWI-001). Â They have aÂ 250 kbps RF data rates and operate atÂ 2.4 GHz. Â These radios use the IEEE 802.15.4 networking protocol and canÂ performÂ point-to-multi-point or peer-to-peer networking , but as configured here, they do not mesh. Â The Digi models that handle meshing are Digimesh, ZNet2.5 and Zigbee (ZB). Â Digimesh is a version of firmware that runs on Series 1 hardware. So, if you choose to, you can upgrade these modules to Digimesh firmware to get meshing.

Xbee Adapter Board

Along with the XBee radios, I purchased adapter boards designed to make it easier to work with the radios. The adopter providesÂ on-boardÂ 3.3V regulator power from a 5 volt source, voltage level shifting circuitry so you can connect Â 5V circuitry to the XBee,Â commonly used pins are brought out along the edge (making it easy to breadboard), andÂ engineered to be interface via FTDI cable to a computer via USB. Â TheÂ image and the textÂ belowÂ describeÂ theÂ pin-outÂ for the Adafruit Â XBee Adapter:

    1. 3V pinÂ - This is either an input power pin (if 5V is not provided) or an output from the 250mA regulator if 5V is provided
    2. DTRÂ - “Data terminal ready” Â is a flow control pin used to tell the XBee that the microcontroller or computer host is ready to communicate.
    3. RSTÂ - “Reset” Â pin can be used to reset the XBee. Â By default it is pulled high by the 10K resistor under the module. To reset, pull this pin low.’
    4. GroundÂ - common ground for power and signal
    5. CTSÂ - “Clear to Send” this is a flow control pin that can be used to determine if there is data in the XBee input buffer ready to be read
    6. 5VÂ - This is the power input pin into the 3.3V regulator. Provide up to 6V that will be linearly converted into 3.3V
    7. RXÂ - “Receive Data”Â is the XBee’s serial recieve pin. Serial data is sent on this pinÂ intoÂ the XBee to be transmitted wirelessly
    8. TXÂ - “Transmit Data” isÂ the XBee’s serial transmit pin. Serial data is sent on this pinÂ out ofÂ the XBee, after it has been transmitted wirelessly from another module
    9. RTSÂ - “Ready to Send” is a flow control pin that can be used to tell the XBee to signal that the computer or microcontroller needs a break from reading serial data.
    10. see pin #1
The DTR, RTS, RST and RX pins (goingÂ intoÂ the XBee) pass through a level converter chip that brings the levels to 3.3V. Adafruit claims you can use pretty much anywhere between 2.7 to 5.5V data to communicate with the XBee. The breakout pins on the bottom of the board are not level shifted and you should try to keep data going directly into the XBee pin under 3.3V

XBee Initial Configuration and Testing

You need a way to communicate withe the Xbee, via itÂ adapter,Â  to set it up. Â This can be done via Adafruit’s Â USB FTDI TTL-232 Cable, and the DigiÂ X-CTUÂ serial terminal program. Â By the way, the X-CTU user guideÂ describesÂ the many more things it can do beyond theÂ configurationÂ shown here.

    1. Plug in theÂ USB FTDI TTL-232 Cable into a PC USB port. Â If drivers are not installedÂ automaticallyÂ (it didn’t for me), follow the steps at the FTDI site.
    2. Download the X-CTU, double click on the executable file, and follow the instructions to install the program.
    3. Now connect theÂ USB FTDI TTL-232 Cable to the Xbee Adapter as shown in the picture to the right and insert the USB end of the cable to you PC. Â Start the X-CTU.
    4. To connect, configure and upgradingÂ the Xbee, follow the Adafruit instructions for the Xbee Adapter board. Note that if you follow the instructions (I didn’t - I kept it at 9600 baud), the modem’s serialÂ interfaceÂ is now set to 19,200 baud, not theÂ defaultÂ 9600 used by X-CTU. Â RememberÂ this next time you use X-CTU with this Xbee.
    5. If your instructed by X-CTU to reset the Xbee, you can do this by shorting the reset pin, RST pin, Â to ground.
The configuration can be touchy, it can go badly, or not at all. Â In my case, I seem to have one XbeeÂ AdapterÂ that canÂ reliably performÂ aÂ firmwareÂ upgrade but the other oneÂ took some time due to a loseÂ fittingÂ betweenÂ the Adaptor andÂ Â Xbee. Â If you run intoÂ configurationÂ problems, check out these sites:Â Using XCTU to Invoke the Bootloader,Â The Unofficial XBee FAQ, Â How to recover from a failed firmware upgrade.

Quickly Getting the Xbee’s Communicating

The next step for me was just do a basic test of getting two XBee device communicating with each other. This is just a sanity test to see evidence of communication between the devices. Basically, I just followed the instructionsÂ provided by Adafruit.
    1. Using the X-CTU, set the PAN ID to the same value on the two Xbee’s.
    2. Select an Ardunio that has been programmed to send repeated brief messages to its serial port. Â I used the standard LED Blinking sketch but put in some write statements in the loop.
    3. Using an Arduino and breadboard,Â connect +5V and ground to provide power. Make sure the XBee’s LED is blinking.
    4. Connect the RX line (input) of the XBee to the TX line (output) of the Arduino.Â Connect the RX line (input) of the Arduino to the TX line (output) of the Xbee. Plug the Arduino into your PC’s serial port.
    5. Now take the second Xbee and connect theÂ Â USB FTDI TTL-232 Cable to the Xbee and the PC. Â The cable is doing nothing but appling power to the Xbee.
    6. Now you should see the receive LEDÂ periodicallyÂ light on theÂ USB FTDI TTL-232 CableÂ tetheredÂ Xbee.
    7. You now got proof that the two Xbee’s are communicating. Â TheÂ ArduinoÂ connected Xbee is sending data to its serial port and theÂ USB FTDI TTL-232 CableÂ tetheredÂ Xbee isÂ receivingÂ it.
Above you’ll find a picture of theÂ configuration,Â and below is the Arduino sketch I used.

/*
 *  Xbee Test via Blink LED
 *
 *Turns on an LED on for one second, then off for one second, repeatedly.
 *Also increase brigthness of analog LED.
 *
 *The circuit:
 * LED1 connected from digital pin 13 to ground.
 * LED2 connected from analog pin 9 to ground.
 * Note: On most Arduino boards, there is already an LED on the board
 * connected to pin 13, so you don't need any extra components for this example.

 *Created 1 June 2005
 *By David Cuartielles
 *http://arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/Blink
 *based on an orginal by H. Barragan for the Wiring i/o board
 *Modified by Jeff Irland in December 2012
 */

int ledPin1 =  13;    // LED connected to digital pin 13
int ledPin2 =  9;     // LED connected to analog pin 9
int brightness = 0;

// The setup() method runs once, when the sketch starts
void setup()   {
    Serial.begin(9600);
    pinMode(ledPin1, OUTPUT);     // initialize the digital pin as an output
    Serial.println("Arduino done with setup()");
}

// the loop() method runs over and over again,
// as long as the Arduino has power
void loop()
{
    digitalWrite(ledPin1, HIGH);   // set the LED on
    Serial.println("LED set HIGH.");
    delay(1000);                   // wait for a second

    digitalWrite(ledPin1, LOW);    // set the LED off
    Serial.println("LED set LOW.");
    delay(1000);                   // wait for a second

    brightness = brightness + 5;
    analogWrite(ledPin2, brightness);
    Serial.println("LED brightness increased.");
}

Installing XBee Python Tools for the RPi

While the MS Windows basedÂ Digi X-CTUÂ tool is just fine, I want to use the RPi’s and Python to access the XBee serial communication API, and itsÂ advanced features, for one or more XBeeÂ devices. Â I prefer simple utilities, that can be scripted within the Linux shell. Â Call me aÂ LinuxÂ snob if you wish, but I don’t care for MS Windows!

In my post “Selecting XBee Radios and Supporting Software Tools“, IÂ referenced a Python package that could be used to create my utilitiesd, call python-xbee, and I will be using it here.Â It claims to provides a semi-complete implementation of the XBee binary API protocol and allows a developer to send andÂ receive the information they desire without dealing with the raw communication details. It also claims theÂ Â library is compatible with both XBee 802.15.4 (Series 1) and XBee ZigBee (Series 2) modules, normalÂ and PRO.

First, we need to load some additional required Python Packages, that being pySerial and Nose. pySerialÂ extends python’s capabilities to include interacting with a serial port and Nose isÂ a package providing a very easy way to build tests, based on the Python class unittest. Â (Don’t let this all scare you away, these are necessary but your not going to use them directly). Â To load these package:

sudo pip install pySerial
sudo pip install nose

Download the python-xbee tools from Google Code or Python OrgÂ and place them into the RPi’s $HOME/src. Â The README file provides installation instructions. Â It states that the following commandÂ automatically test and install the package for you:

sudo python setup.py install

There is a simple to use RPi platform tool that I have modified for my needs, that is aÂ XBee serial command shell for interacting with XBee radios. Â ItÂ performsÂ the core functions of the official configuration tool, X-CTU, which only runs on Windows.Â (ThereÂ happensÂ to be a cross-platformÂ version of X-CTU calledÂ moltosenso Network ManagerÂ but I don’t need all thisÂ horseÂ power.) Â I’ll use this X-CTU-alternativeÂ to configure the individual XBee radios. Â With the X-CTU, you can update firmware, etc. but most of the time you need the program to do simpleÂ configurationÂ tasks.Â You could use Linux’sÂ minicom, but IÂ preferÂ a simpler tool which can be scripted so I can configure several XBee radiosÂ identically. Â I found much of what I wanted in an existingÂ PythonÂ XBee tools for configuration. Â I made some modification/improvements,Â IÂ call it the XBeeTerm, and its listed below:

The XBeeTerm.py module imports functions from the pretty.py package, specifically to colorize the output for xterm on the Raspberry Pi. Â This package is provided here:

IdentifyingÂ the RPi USB device used by the XBee

Since the python-xbee library wants to talk to the via a Linux serial devices, I’m using theÂ USB FTDI TTL-232 CableÂ (FTDI is the USB chipÂ manufacturer) used in the XBee configuration step done earlier. Â I connected the cable to the RPi USB port Â and then we need to find theÂ serialÂ tty the cable is associated with. Â To do this, it takes a bit of detective work. Run the commands:

lsusb
dmesg | grep Manufacturer
dmesg | grep FTDI

A better command might be (but I’m not sure it will work every time):

dmesg | grep -i usb | grep -i tty

TheÂ interpretationÂ of the output tells us the cable is attached to serial device /dev/ttyUSB0. Â See the output below.

AnotherÂ possibilityÂ is to useÂ udevadm to gather information about specific devices but I never figured outÂ exactlyÂ how to use it toÂ answerÂ my question. Â Python also has a package called PyUSB that might provide some help, but also here you’ll still need the vendor and product identification information.

Chances are that when you plug the cable into the same USB port the next time, it willÂ defaultÂ to the same tty but there is no certainty. Â To assign a permanentÂ tty name to the device, and never do any of this again, check outÂ Persistent names for usb-serial devices.

Configuring the XBee Radios for API Mode

The configuration and testing of the XBee’s done earlier was done inÂ AT Command mode (Transparent Mode). In AT mode,Â everything sent to the RX line of the XBee radio will be sent out via the antenna, and all the incoming data from antenna will go to the XBee’s TX line. Â This is why we could check the sanity of the XBee radios in the earlier section,Â XBee Initial Configuration and Testing using a simple ArduinoÂ sketch. Â We sent junk to the XBee and it transmitted it!

Now we’ll configure two XBee radios (with a Coordinator and a single End Device) to form a network using API Mode. Â In API Mode, XBee won’t send out anything until it received the correct form of commands from the serial interface. Â TheÂ XBeeÂ AT Command SetÂ (page 27),Â specificallyÂ the Â ATAP 2 command, allows you to configure the XBee radio for API Mode. Â  So why API Mode, consider the following:

    • When sending a packet, the transmitting radio receives an ACK, indicating the packet was successfully delivered. The transmitting radio will resend the packet if it does not receive an ACK.
    • Receive packets (RX), contain the source address of transmitting radio
    • You can configure a remote radio with the Remote AT feature
    • Easily address multiple radios and send broadcast TX packets
    • Receive I/O data from 1 or more remote XBees
    • Obtain RSSI (signal strength) of an RX packet
    • Packets include a checksum for data integrity
The XBeeTerm utility will Â easily configure the XBee radios for API mode and set theÂ appropriateÂ network parameters. Â To get aÂ deeperÂ appreciationÂ of configuringÂ the XBee radios, see theÂ ReferencesÂ at the end. Â For here, I’ll just runÂ throughÂ the steps using the XBeeTerm.py tool and the configuration commands used, documented in file scripts.

Coordinator Configuration File: Config-Coordinator.txt

End DeviceÂ ConfigurationÂ File: Config-End-Device.txt

As they stand right now, these files could not be processed byÂ XBeeTerm.py because of the comments (included to make the contents understandable). Â To clean this up, the commandÂ sed '/^#/d; s/([^$])#./\1/'will remove all shell type comments from a file andÂ sed 's/[ \t]$//'will remove unneeded white space. Â Putting this all together and you can use this toÂ prepareÂ the above files forÂ XBeeTerm.py:

sed '/^#/d; s/\([^$]\)#.*/\1/' Config-Coordinator.txt | sed 's/[ \t]*$//' > coord.txt
sed '/^#/d; s/\([^$]\)#.*/\1/' Config-End-Device.txt | sed 's/[ \t]*$//' > endd.txt

Now execute the following python XBeeTerm.py coord.txtÂ and you get the output below:

The yellow text isÂ responsesÂ back from the XBee serial terminal and the red text is from the XBee radio itself. Â Since all the red text is “OK”, all the commands took and the XBee radio is now configured as aÂ Coordinator. Â Now repeat this for the End Device XBee radio.

In this example, I have one End Device but what if you have multiple devices, do you need aÂ Config-End-Device.txtÂ file for each end device? Â The only change within the configuration file is the radio’s address, which is established via the ATMY command. Â Here is a trick to avoid the need for multiple files. Â First, configure all your End Devices using the configuration file. Â Then, for each radio, modify the ATMY use the following:

echo -e "baudrate 9600\nserial /dev/ttyUSB0\n+++\nATMY AAA1\nATWR\nATFR\nexit" | python XBeeTerm.py

but for eachÂ End Device radio, increment the ATMY address by one (e.g. AAA2, AAA3, …).

Querying XBee for Configuration

Now that weÂ believeÂ the XBee radios are properly configured, lets verify that by query the radios. Â You could use XBeeTerm toÂ performÂ this function by including only the AT Command without the parameter but I wanted a more informative tool. For this, I have created another utility that can take a list of AT Commands as arguments and query the XBee radio for the AT’s parameter value. Â This utility, call XBeeQuery.py, is listed below:

Here is a sample output for the XBeeQuery utility:

item.title: Selecting XBee Radios and Supporting Software Tools
item.description:
My ultimate aim is to wirelessly network several Arduino basedÂ platformsÂ with a centralized Raspberry PiÂ controller or gateway. Â There is much for me to learn to get this operational, not the least of which is the selection of the radio device platform I plan to use. After reviewingÂ otherÂ devices,Â I have settled on the XBee, in part because of its popularity, its mesh capabilities, and it power management. Â To get up to speed on theÂ Xbee, I found the tutorials atÂ Adafruit,Â Sparkfun, andÂ ParallaxÂ helpful. Â  Some additional goodÂ referencesÂ are listed at the end of this post.

As I did in the postÂ Raspberry Pi Serial Communication: What, Why, and a Touch ofÂ How, I have a desire (obsessiveÂ need?) to do some extensive researching before diving into implementing a project. Â What is listed below are my research findings.

XBee Series 1 vs. Series 2

Digi’s XBee website gives you a confusing set of options forÂ selectingÂ radios but after reviewingÂ multipleÂ sources, it boils down to theÂ XBee Series 1 vs. Series 2 for the DIY type applications I would do.
    • XBeeÂ SeriesÂ 1 Module (Freescale technology with 802.15.4 firmware)Â have aÂ 250 kbps RF data rates and operate atÂ 2.4 GHz. Â These radios use the IEEE 802.15.4 networking protocol and canÂ performÂ point-to-multi-point networking. Â You can also doÂ peer-to-peerÂ networking (a form ofÂ meshÂ network) but this will require a firmware Â upgradeÂ calledÂ DigiMeshÂ designedÂ specificallyÂ for the Series 1 hardware.
    • XBeeÂ Series 2 Module (Ember/Silicon Labs technology with ZigBee firmware) are similar to the Series 1 in many respects but use the ZigBee standard, and Â therefore, have the potential forÂ interoperability with devices made by different vendors.
Mesh networkingÂ (topology)Â is a type of networking where eachÂ nodeÂ must not only capture and disseminate its own data, but also may serve as aÂ relayÂ for other nodes, that is, it must collaborate to propagate the data in the network. Â This gives the networkÂ self configuring,Â self healing,Â dynamic routing, and other capabilities. Â Wireless mesh networks can be implemented with various wireless technology includingÂ 802.11,Â 802.15,Â 802.16, cellular technologies or combinations of more than one type. Â The mesh enabling capability for these technologies is theÂ routing protocolÂ being used.Â There areÂ many routing protocolsÂ being used by mesh networks today for manyÂ differentÂ types of products, but I will concern ourselves with just the XBee Series 1 and Series 2 products.

TheÂ Zigbee AllianceÂ is a group of more than 300 companiesÂ who is responsible for publishing and maintaining the Zigbee specification. In the ZigBee network topology,Â Â there are different node types in the network (Coordinator, Router, End Device).Â DigiMeshÂ is a proprietaryÂ peer-to-peer networkingÂ using aÂ simplified topology (no need to define and organize coordinators, routers or end-nodes). Â Digi has a white paper that does a nice comparison of the two types of meshing products.

To further clarify the similarity/differenceÂ betweenÂ Series 1 & 2, see the table below:

Feature

XBee Series 1 / 802.15.4

XBee Series 2 / ZigBee

Ramifications

Price

~ $23

~ $26

Price shouldnât be a driver but If you are looking for a simple point-to-point configuration, you should go with the Series 1. The Series 2 requires considerable setup and configuration.

Transmit Power OutputÂ 

Indoor/Urban RangeÂ 

Line-of-Sight Range

1 mW (0dbm)

up to 100 ft.

up to 300 ft.

2 mW (+3dbm)

up to 133 ft.

up to 400 ft.

The additional power of the Series 2 give you a ~25% increase in range.

Firmware

Comes standard with 802.15.4 firmware for point-point or star topology. Requires DigiMesh firmware to mesh.

does not offer any 802.15.4-only firmware; it is always running the XBee ZB ZigBee mesh firmware

DigiMesh, while proprietary, appears to have less overhead and easier to configure

Network Topologies

Point-to-Point, Star, and Mesh (with DigiMesh firmware)

Point-to-Point, Star, and Mesh

With a closer reading of the specs, youâll find that the Series 1 with DigiMesh has a peer-to-peer topology but the Series 2 is hierarchical. I believe peer-to-peer is superior.

Routing Protocol

Ad hoc On-Demand Distance Vector (AODV) Routing +Â Hierarchical Tree Routing as last resort

Ad hoc On-Demand Distance Vector (AODV) Routing

I suspect there are more differences here but couldnât uncover them.

RF Data Rate

250 Kbps

250 Kbps

RF data rate doesnât have much practical meaning

Practical Maximum Throughput

~ 80kbps

ZigBee is significantly slower than the 802.15.4

ZugBee is a full OSI stack, and as a result, has significant overhead.

Power-Down Current

10 uA

1 uA

Series 2 was built for low power consumption.

After pondering this all for a bit, I believe the choose boils down to two questions:

    • Is theÂ interoperability of ZigBeeÂ importantÂ to you?
    • What are the benefits of ZigBee vs. DigiMesh?
The answer to the first question is “no”. Â While I find ZigBee’s interoperability seductive, theÂ practicalÂ matter is that I just don’t see that many applications that I couldÂ envisionÂ integratingÂ into a project. Â Maybe some day, but not within my planningÂ horizon. Â As to the second question, I don’t see any advantages to ZigBee’s imposed topology ofÂ coordinators, routers, and end-nodes. Â I believe theÂ homogeneousÂ types of nodes will give my applications the flexibility I may need.Â Of course, there are many other things one might want to consider, but I think this analysis is sufficient for my needs. Â I’m going with theÂ XBeeÂ SeriesÂ 1 Module and I’ll install DigiMesh firmware when it comes time to build meshed networks.

AT Mode vs. API Mode

XBee modules support two modes of operation â AT mode and API mode. Â In API mode, you communicate with the radio by sending and receiving packets. In AT (transparent) mode, the XBee radio simply relays serial data to the receiving XBee, as identified by the DH+DL address. Â Series 1 radios support both AT and API modes with a single firmware version, allowing you switch between the modes with the Â X-CTU software.

To create simple point-to-point links, XBee works nicely in AT mode without much coding. However, if your goal is to build a network consisting of more than two devices, AT mode becomes too difficult to bear. You will spend almost all the time switching in and out of AT mode, wasting time and draining batteries in the process. On the other hand, in API mode commands and data travel in specially formatted frames and no switching is necessary. Another advantage of API mode is that serial speed on transmittersÂ doesn’tÂ have to match â one can be configured for 115,200bps, another for 2400bps, third left with default 9600bps. There is another nice feature called remote command; you can remotely request the state of XBee module pins, for example, or change an output pin level.

It’s clear that I’ll want to work in API mode, but judging from the examples of XBee API mode code, itÂ sureÂ would be nice to have aÂ libraryÂ package that has designed in some basic utilities that I can leverage. Â That is the next topic.

Supporting Software

One of the first packages IÂ discoveredÂ was the Xbee Network Protocol (XNP). Â I was impressed by the volume and quality of the documentation. Â Never the less, I passed on it for two reasons. Â First, it isn’t as mature as other packages I discovered (and not widely used), and mostÂ importantly, it appears to be implementing meshÂ networkingÂ in software. Â Ether the author didn’tÂ recognizeÂ that the Series 1 modules can mesh via the DigiMesh firmware (not a surprise since manyÂ websitesÂ wrongfully report that the Series 1 do not mesh) or he just wants to roll-his-own (what better way to learn about mesh routingÂ protocols).

xbee-arduinoÂ is a C++ Arduino library for communicating with XBees in API mode, with support for both Series 1 and Series 2. Â Judging from the documentation,Â Â it appears that it could be ported to Raspberry Pi but it would be far easier to use something targeted for the RPi (see below). Â With the latest beta software, the XBee’s serial communications can be handle via SoftwareSerial, freeing up the Arduino USB for debugging. Â It also appears to that the author isÂ experimentingÂ  if not alreadyÂ supporting DigiMesh. The package is well documented,Â activelyÂ maintained, andÂ equallyÂ important, appears to be popular.

AnotherÂ possibility for the Raspberry PiÂ is theÂ python-xbee. ThisÂ Python package is not as well documented as the xbee-arduino but does appear to be actively used and supported. The fact that its on the Python Organization’s web site as a listed package gives it someÂ additionalÂ credibility.Â SeeÂ thisÂ andÂ thisÂ with respect to DigiMesh support.

libxbee is another C++ library but targeted at Linux and Windows. Fewer users and the author states “development is coming to an end” may mean thisÂ platformÂ isn’t as strong as the others.

While not a veryÂ rigorous analysis, I believe I’ll place my bets on xbee-arduino for Arduino development and python-xbee for Raspberry Pi development. Â Using Python is intriguing in part because it appears to be the preferred software language for the RPi.Â  But what if you have some C++ code, a popular language for Linux, and that you want to use some existing libraries? There are tools that could make this happen. You could use Python’s C/C++ extension modules. Also, there is theÂ Simplified Wrapper and Interface Generator (SWIG), which isÂ a software development tool that connects programs written in C/C++ with a variety of high-level programming languages. SWIG is used with different types of target languages including common scripting languages such as Perl, PHP, Python, Tcl and Ruby.

References

An unspoken consideration in my analysis isÂ documentation availability/quality, example implementations Â for learning, and theÂ availabilityÂ of software libraries I could potential use. Here are some of the more interesting things I uncovered.

Tutorials (ZigBee but can be generalized to the XBee)

    • Zigbee Tutorial - a short introduction
    • 802.15.4 vs ZigBee - a more technical introduction
    • Zigbee Mesh Routing - Interactive Tutorial - nice job explainingÂ AODV routing
    • The ZigBee Standard - a painless introduction
XBeeÂ Documentation
    • XBeeÂ SeriesÂ 1 Manuals - multiple document covering the Series 1 modual
    • The Unofficial XBee FAQÂ Â - answers to issues that maybe getting in the way
    • XBee Cookbook for Series 1 - sort of companion document to the The Unoffical XBee FAQ
    • Libelium.com Development DocumentationÂ - while targeted for theÂ meshlium device, this does have good general documenation
Example Implementations
    • Collection of XBee Projects - Digi’s collection of XBee projects done by the Hacker/DIY community
    • XBeeÂ Examples & Guides - Digi’s website giving you step-by-step instructions for simple projects
    • Playing Xbee: Part 1, 2, 3, 4 - author does a nice “teaching tour” on his introduction to XBee
Other Sources
    • mesh networks research groupÂ - informative topicsÂ focused in the mesh networks field
    • Driver Module for XBee Device -Â Linux kernel driver for XBee
