item.title: Raspberry Pi Serial Communication: What, Why, and a Touch of How
item.description:
I started exploring how to get a LCD display operational with a Raspberry Pi (RPi). Â I checked out two hardware configurations: the bare boneÂ LCD 16x2 display driven by theÂ HD44780 chip set,Â which takes 6 wires to operate, Â and anotherÂ configurationÂ that uses aÂ Adafruit shield that requires only 2 wires. Â It quickly became clear to me that I knew very little about how the LCD display works (maybe not an important topic for me) and I didn’t fully understands the RPi’sÂ serialÂ communicationsÂ capabilities (something I must fully understand). Â Adafruit does give some niceÂ tutorialÂ that Â provide instructions on how to get bothÂ configurationsÂ work on the RPi, but I don’t like blindly follow tutorials without having a deeper understanding of my options and the underlining hardware. Â  So what are the serial communication options supported by theÂ RaspberryÂ Pi, under what situationsÂ wouldÂ you use them, and how do you use them?

So I did my research, and for the moment, I’m not going to concern myself about LCD displays but I will dive neck deep into understanding RPi serial communications. Â I’ll return to the LCD display topic later.

The Raspberry Pi Board

As our first step, lets take a quickÂ scanÂ of the interfaces we have on RPi for moving data in and out. Â TheÂ pictureÂ belowÂ labelsÂ the mostÂ prominentÂ componentsÂ on the RPi board.

Of course, the “lead actor” on the RPi board is the Broadcom BCM2835, System on a Chip (SoC). Â Broadcom bills this chip as a “multimedia applications processor for advanced mobile and embedded applications that require the highest levels of multimedia performance”. Â Maybe moreÂ importantlyÂ for the DIY/Hacker community is that all theÂ firmwareÂ running on the chip is now open source.

There is another big chip, that being the SMSCÂ LAN9512/LAN9512iÂ USB Â Hub &Â Ethernet Controller. Â This is the major workÂ horseÂ in getting data in/out of the RPi for USB peripheral devicesÂ and IP networking.

Now note that most of the board’s other large componentsÂ are for data I/O. Â Specifically, the HDMI, RCA Video, and Audio Out (3.5mm jack) are output only (at least for general purpose data communicationÂ perspective), andÂ therefore, not part of our discussion. Â On the other hand, theÂ USB and EthernetÂ ports, are powerful Â and widely supported serial communication devices, but I will onlyÂ lightlyÂ touch the USB. I want to focus on serialÂ communicationÂ with simple/bare-boneÂ devices, like an LCD 16x2 display, which generally are not interface via something asÂ sophisticatedÂ at USB or Ethernet. Â But the USB can be used to some for some types of device interfacing, so I will cover that as a final topic.

There are three other boardÂ componentsÂ that concern themselves with data communications but will not be covered in this post:

  • JTAG Header:Â TheÂ JTAGÂ Header is used as aÂ debug port.Â Embedded systemsÂ developer relies onÂ debuggersÂ communicating with chips via the JTAG to perform operations likeÂ single steppingÂ andÂ break-pointing. Â In time, I suspect people will find ways toÂ exploitÂ these pins for both good &Â evil, but for now, this is for the RPi hardware development community to use.
  • CSI Camera Connector:Â TheÂ Camera Serial Interface (CSI)Â  specificationÂ is a standard interface between a camera and a host processor for mobile device applications. Â This will be where you’ll connectÂ camerasÂ and video devices to the RPi.
  • DSI Display Connector:Â TheÂ Display Serial InterfaceÂ (DSI)Â is a specification Â aimed at reducing the cost ofÂ display sub-systemsÂ in aÂ mobile device. This is commonly targeted atÂ LCDÂ and similar display technologies.Â RPi may be able to interface to some of these. Â Some graphical LCD/OLED displays might be attached to it. Â DSI would seem like a good candidate for implementing my LCD display but there is a problem. Â It appears theÂ DSI isn’t supportedÂ at this time.
This leaves one remaining board input/outputÂ componentÂ standing, that be theÂ General Purpose Input/OutputÂ (GPIO). Â On some electronics boards,Â GPIO pins have no special purpose defined, and some pins go unused by default. Â The RPi developer has identifiedÂ a handful of digital control lines and provided services on them for you to use. Â By having these available can save you the hassle of having to arrange additional circuitry to provide them or implement functionality in software.

Raspberry Pi’s GPIO as a Data Bus The first thing to get your head around, is how is data moved around the RPi, or in anyÂ generalÂ purposeÂ computer. Â In the most general sense in electronics, a bus or data bus is used to move data words of any type from one place to another. Computing is based on data words made up of collections of data bits. These âwordsâ can contain as few as four data bits and often much larger.

The task of a bus designer is to devise circuitry that passes these data words from one circuit to another. Â These words can be communicatedÂ seriallyÂ Â (i.e.Â serial communications)Â or inÂ parallel.

  • Serial Bus:Â The least expensive method in terms ofÂ wire cost is to send the bits one at a time over a single pair of wires. This is called serial dataÂ transmission. Â Data words start as sets of bits that exist inÂ parallel. In order to ship these words on a serial basis they must be converted to a serial streamÂ of bits at the transmit end and then reconverted to a parallel word at the receive end. TheÂ common name for the circuitry that does this conversion is aÂ SerDesÂ circuit which stands forÂ serializer/deserializer. Integrated circuits are more expensive when they have more pins. To reduce the number of pins in a package, many ICs use a serial bus to transfer data when speed is not important. Some examples of such low-cost serial buses includeÂ Serial Peripheral InterfaceÂ (SPI),Â Inter-Integrated CircuitÂ (IÂ²C),Â UNI/O, andÂ 1-Wire.
  • Parallel Bus:Â At some point, it is more cost effective to add a wire for each bit in theÂ word and send it in parallel on a data bus.Â ParallelÂ busesÂ have a limited data rate and distance at which they can be reliably run (more so than aÂ serialÂ bus). Â Some widely used parallel bus standards areÂ Parallel Bus InterfaceÂ (PBI),Â Peripheral Component InterfaceÂ (PCI),Â Small Computer SystemsÂ InterfaceÂ (SCSI), theÂ VMEbusÂ used in instrumentation, theÂ RambusÂ interfaceÂ used in memories, and others.
As the name implies, GPIO pins can be configuredÂ through softwareÂ  to provide some specific function or purpose within the hardware device design. Â The GPIO pins connect directly into the core of theÂ processor, and the Raspberry Pi developers implemented several alternate functions for the GPIO pins. Â SeveralÂ are desirable because of the multiple standards and types of devices you may wish to interface. Â OnÂ boot-up,Â  the RPi board GPIO is in alternate function state “ALT0” and will support I2C, SPI, and UART. Â This is shown below:

It can beÂ confusingÂ to call the RPi’s whole 26 pin array GPIO and also some specific pins GPIO. Â  InÂ reality, all the GPIO pins can be reconfigured to provide alternate functions.Â 

While PCM isn’t a topic for this posting, in the figure above, you’ll also seeÂ referencesÂ to PCM on pins 18 & 21. Â PCM stands forÂ Pulse-code modulationÂ and isÂ s a method used toÂ digitallyÂ representÂ analog signals. Â It is often used to control light intensity or motors. Â RPi’s native PCM capabilities are not well documented but it appears that people have has some success. Â Generally, to do anything useful, you need multiple PCM channels so people haveÂ resortedÂ to adding hardware or software to get the desired functionality from the RPi. Â My guess is these RPi pins don’t have much of a future.

I2C, SPI, UART … Say what?

Much has been lightly covered so far, including terms like I2C, SPI, and UART. Â So what is the significance? Â Well,Â I2C, SPI, and UART are the heart of our quest to understand RPi’s serial communications capability. Via their exposure on the GPIO pins, these capabilities are what can be used to integrate things like LCD displays to the RPi. Â Now lets dive deeper into each one of them.

Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitter (UART)

TheÂ Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitter (UART)Â takes bytes of data and transmits the individual bits in a sequential fashion.Â The device changesÂ processor’s parallel information to serial data which can be sent on a communication line. A second UART (maybe on anotherÂ processor) Â can be used to receive the serial information. The UART performs all the tasks, timing, parity checking, etc. needed for the communication. The only extra devices attached are line driver chips capable of transforming the TTL level signals (0/5 volts) to line voltages (on RS-232 line this could be as +/- 25 volts) and vice versa.

Each UART contains aÂ shift register, which is the fundamental method of conversion between serial and parallel forms. Serial transmission of digital information (bits) through a single wire or other medium is much more cost effective than parallel transmission through multiple wires. Â The UARTs transmit/receiveÂ one bit at a time at a specified data rate (i.e. 9600bps, 115,200bps, etc.). This method of serial communication is sometimes referred to asÂ TTL serial communications.

Asynchronous transmission allows data to be transmitted without the sender having to send a clock signal to the receiver. Instead, the sender and receiver must agree on timing parameters in advance and special bits are added to each word which are used to synchronize the sending and receiving units.Â When a word is given to the UART for Asynchronous transmissions, a bit called the “Start Bit” is added to the beginning of each word that is to be transmitted. The Start Bit is used to alert the receiver that a word of data is about to be sent, and to force the clock in the receiver into synchronization with the clock in the transmitter.

For a furtherÂ descriptionÂ ofÂ synchronous and asynchronous line communications, check out thisÂ tutorial.

Raspberry Pi’s Mini-UART

Warning: Misleading information ahead - See Warren Gay’s comments. The Raspberry PiÂ actuallyÂ hasÂ two UARTs. One UART Â is part of the internal ARM architecture of the Broadcom BCM2835 chip, in the core of the Raspberry Pi and not accessibleÂ externally. Â The other UART is sometimes calledÂ the RPi’s “Serial Port” (even thou the USB supportsÂ serial communications, and therefore aÂ serialÂ port).Â Â The serial port beingÂ referenceÂ here is serviced by a UART, sometimeÂ refereedÂ to as theÂ Â âMini-UART” since it doesn’t appear to be very rich in functionality. Â It is basically be used as a console port for access to the Raspberry Pi. Â The serial console is a convenient way to interact with the Raspberry Pi for debugging or your network is down and it is the destination of console messages (including boot-up messages).Â  From theÂ Raspberry Pi pinoutÂ and theÂ eLinux wiki, I can see that the serial port (aka Mini-UART) on the Pi is on GPIO Pin 14 (TX) and GPIO Pin 15 (RX):

Since the GPIO pins give access to the Mini UART, you can establish a serial console, which can be used to log in to the Pi, and many other things. Â However, normal console device communicate with -12V (logical â1â³) and +12V (logical â0â³) RS-232, which may just fry something in the 3.3V Pi. Even âTTL levelâ serial at 5V runs the same risk. Â SeeÂ this tutorialÂ for one example on how to build 3.3V to RS-232 levels converter with aÂ MAX3232CPE and a few passiveÂ components.

You can reconfigure the RPi so that the Mini UART isn’t acting as a serial console and use it for outer purposes (e.g. communicate with an attached Arduino or Xbee). Â Using the Raspberry Piâs serial portÂ requires some Linux reconfiguration and theÂ abandonmentÂ of the serial console, and potentially some level conversion, but it could be useful. TheÂ Mini-UART pins to provide access to Linux’s /dev/ttyAMA0 serial port.Â  To be able to use the serial port to connect and talk to other devices, the serial port console login needs to be disabled and the post “Raspberry Pi and the Serial Port” shows you how.

Again, keep in mind thatÂ RX and TX lines are available on theÂ GPIOsÂ but operate at 3.3 volts. You’ll need a board or cable toÂ level convertÂ 3.3 volt UART signals to connect with other devices (e.g. RS-232, USB).

Serial Peripheral Interface Bus (SPI) — aka 4-Wire Serial Bus

TheÂ Serial Peripheral Interface Bus or SPIÂ (pronounced as either S-P-I or spy) bus is a synchronous serial data link standard, named by Motorola, that operates in full duplex mode.Â Â SPI is much simpler than I2C. Master and slave are linked by three data wires, usually called MISO, (Master in, Slave out), MOSI (Master out, Slave in), the SCLK clock line (sometimes called M-CLK), and an optionalÂ SS (Slave Select; sometimes known as the ChipÂ SelectÂ or CS line or Chip Enable or CE line) is the slave select or chip select line. Â Its optional only if you have one slave, otherwise one or more SS lines are provided. Â The Raspberry Pi has two Slave Select lines: CE0 and CE1.

Usually the transfer sequence consist of driving the SS line low, sending X number of clock signals with the proper polarity and phase, then driving the SS line high to end the communication.Â As the clock signals are generated, data is transferred in both directions, therefore in a âtransmit onlyâ system the received bytes have to be discarded and in a âreceive onlyâ system a dummy byte has to be transmitted.

Many SPI-enabled ICs and Microcontrollers can cope with data rates of over 10MHz, so transfer is much faster than with I2C. Since it is synchronousÂ communications, it is not limited to 8-bit words so you can send any message sizes with arbitrary content and purpose. The SPI interface does not require pull-up resistors, which translates to lower power consumption. The downside is that SPI normally has no addressing capability;Â instead, devices are selected by means of a SS signal which the master can use to enable one slave out of several connected to the SPI bus.Â If more than one slave exists, one chip select line is required per device, which can use precious GPIO lines on the Master.

Inter-Integrated Circuit (I2C) — aka 2-Wire Serial Bus

Inter-Integrated Circuit or I2CÂ (pronounced as either I-squared-C or I-2-C) is generically referred to as a “two-wire interface”. Â It’s a multi-masterÂ serial single-ended computer bus invented by Philips that is used to attach low-speed peripherals to a motherboard, embedded system, cellphone, or other electronic device.

I2C can be used to connect up to 127 nodes via a busÂ has two data wires, called SCL and SDA. Â SCL is the clock line. It is used to synchronize all data transfers over the I2C bus. SDA is the data line. Of course, there is a third wire being ground. There may also be a 5 volt wire to distribute power to the devices. Both SCL and SDA lines are “open drain” drivers. What this means is that the chip can drive its output low, but it cannot drive it high. Â For the line to be able to go high you must provide pull-up resistors to the 5v supply. There should be a resistor from the SCL line to the 5v line and another from the SDA line to the 5v line. The value of the resistors is not critical. Â Anything from 1800 ohms to 47K ohms used (1.8K, 47K and 10K are common values). You only need one set of pull-up resistors for the whole I2C bus, not for each device, as illustrated below:

In theory the I2C bus can support multiple masters, but most micro-controllers canât. A master is usually a microcontroller, although it doesnât have to be. Slaves can be ICs or microcontrollers. Â When the master wishes to communicate with a slave it sends a series of pulses down the SDA and SCL lines. The data that is sent includes an address that identifies the slave with which the master needs to interact. Addresses take 7 bits out of a data byte; the remaining bit specifies whether the master wishes to read (get data from a slave) or write (send data to a slave).

Some devices have an address that is entirely fixed by the manufacturer; others can be configured to take one of a range of possible addresses. When a micro-controller is used as a slave it is normally possible to configure its address by software, and for that address to take on any of the 127 possible values. Â The address byte may be followed by one or more byes of data, which may go from master to slave or from slave to master.

When data is being sent on the SDA line, clock pulses are sent on the SCL line to keep master and slave synchronised. Since the data is sent one bit at a time,Â the data transfer rate is one eighth of the clock rate. The original standard specified a standardÂ clock rate of 100KHz, and most I2C chips and micro-controllers can support this.Â Later updates to the standard introduced aÂ fastÂ speed of 400KHz and aÂ highÂ speed of 1.7 or 3.4 MHz. Â The Arduino and Raspberry Pi can support standard and fast speeds.

The fast rate corresponds to a data transfer rate of 50K bytes/sec which is too slow for some control applications. One option in that case is to use SPI instead of I2C.

1-Wire — aka 1-WireÂ SerialÂ Bus

On aÂ 1-WireÂ bus (sometime refered to as aÂ Â ”MicroLan”), a single master device communicates with one or more 1-Wire slave devices over a single data line, which can also be used to provide power to the slave devices. Devices drawing power from the 1-wire bus are said to be operating inparasitic powerÂ mode. Â When operating in parasite power mode, only two wires are required: one data wire, and ground. At the master,Â a 4.7k pull-up resistor must be connected to the 1-wire bus.Â With an external supply, three wires are required: the bus wire, ground, and power.Â The 4.7k pull-up resistor is still requiredÂ on the bus wire.

Each 1-Wire device contains a unique 64-bit Â code, consisting of an 8-bit family code, a 48-bit serial number, and an 8-bit CRC.Â Before sending a command to a slave device, the master must first select that device using its code.

How do you use I2C, SPI, UART, or 1-Wire on the Raspberry Pi?

Now that we know the what & why for serial communications options on the Raspberry Pi, how do we use them? Â This topic deserves technical details and examples but this post has already run too long. Â I’m likely to do some specificÂ implementationÂ in the future, but for now I’llÂ referenceÂ some sources of information on the web.

First, lets be clear about the RPi software distribution I’m using, since not all will be supporting all these serial communications options. Â I’m using Adafruit’sÂ OccidentalisÂ distribution (based on “Wheezy”) which comes with hardwareÂ SPI,Â I2C, and 1-wireÂ support. In the Occidentalis distribution, Adafruit has included in the LinuxÂ kernelÂ the needed drivers.Â SPI and I2C has been implement on the GPIO pins as outline above. Â RPi doesn’t have a predetermined GPIO pin assignment for 1-Wire, but Adafruit choose GPIO pin 4 for 1-Wire. Â Note that thisÂ unassignedÂ GPCLK0 (General Purpose Clock Voltage) function.

Given you have the OccidentalisÂ distribution, you can check on the installation of I2C, SPI, and 1-Wire via the following:

    • To validate I2C, connect any I2C device to power, ground, SDA and SCL. Then run Â sudoÂ i2cdetect -y 0Â to detect which addresses are on the bus. i2cdetect is aÂ program to scan an I2C bus for devices. Â Also, you can list the I2C device drivers via the commandÂ ls /dev/i2c. Â ThisÂ illustratesÂ that RPi supports two I2C buses, 0 and 1.
    • To validate SPI, the command ls /dev/spi will list two SPI devices, one each for the 0 & 1 SS lines. Â To go further, use theÂ Â spidev_test.cÂ toolÂ describedÂ inÂ Getting SPI working on the Raspberry Pi.
    • Occidentalis implementation ofÂ 1-Wire isn’t done via a kernel installed driverÂ butÂ bitbanged. Â Adafruit states that the implementation isÂ Â ”flakier than SPI or I2C” and they don’t have anyÂ tutorials. Â Maybe 1-Wire should be shelved for now.
There are some goodÂ RPi SPI & I2C tutorials on Adafruits. Â There are others on personal blogs but generally they are scares right now.

Attach PeripheralsÂ to the Raspberry Pi

Now that we know the in’s & out’s of serial communications with the RPi, what can be done to make the physical aspects of interfacing the board easier. Â Dealing with the GPIO pins on the board can be a pain. Â One solution is theÂ Pi CobblerÂ whichÂ plug the GPIO pins into aÂ solderless breadboard via a ribbon cable. Â My personalÂ favoriteÂ is theÂ Pi Crust. Â In this case, the confusing layout of Â GPIO pins are much more clearly organized and supplied with more usefulÂ female headers. Â A wholeÂ developmentÂ environmentÂ will be supplied viaÂ PiFace Digital and GertboardÂ … when they becomeÂ available.

The USB Serial Ports

As promised, the final topic is the USB port. TheÂ USB can be used for some types of device interfacing,Â particularlyÂ if you make it look like a simple serial port to the device. Â The conventional serial port (not the newer USB port) is a very old I/O (Input/Output) port. It’s slow compared to newer Universal Serial Bus (USB) serial devices, but conventional serial ports are still in use and many devices youâll hook to your RPi will want to use them.Â  Until around 2006, most new desktop PC’s had one but has been largely replaced by the USB. Conventional serial ports are still widely used in embedded systems, but the RPi choose to use the USB.Â  Never the less, it is possible to put a conventional serial port device on the USB bus by using a Serial to USB Adapter hardware or cables.Â  This could be necessary for some of the hardware hacking youâll do with an RPi.Â  (For example, Iâll be posting a project where Iâll use the RPiâs USB to talk to a XBee radio.)

USB does synchronous communications (synchronous means that bytes are sent out at a constant rate one after another in step with a clock signal tick) and transmits in special packets like a network. Conventional serial ports are typically asynchronous (i.e. “not synchronous”). Just like a network, USB can have several devices physically attached to it, including serial ports. Each device on it gets a time-slice of exclusive use for a short time. A device can also be guaranteed the use of the bus at fixed intervals. One device can monopolize it if no other device wants to use it.

Under Linux, each and every hardware device, including USB ports, are treated as a file and call a device file. Â A device file allows a user to access hardware devices, but shields the users from the technical details about the hardware. (This is unlike what weâll see for the RPi GPIO interfaces where hardware level technical details must be address directly.) Under Linux, a conventional serial port will typically have a device file such as /dev/ttyS0, /dev/ttyS1, etc. but the USB serial ports will appear as /dev/ttyUSB0, /dev/ttyUSB1, etc.Â  When your device is plugged in, Linux assigns the filename as it sees fit and isnât always predicable (it doesnât have to be this way). If you need to know what device file your serial device is connected too (and your software often needs to know), using a combination of the commands lsusb, dmesg, and grep, plus some basic insight, will often do the trick.

The lsusb command can show you the hubs connected to your system, but you won’t necessarily see any entries in /dev until you plug something into it, and what that entry may be will be dependent upon the type of device you are plugging in.Â  The system doesn’t recognize new USB devices right away. It can take from a couple of seconds to as much as a minute. Â If I plug my Serial to USB Adapter cable, using the lsusb command I can identify the cables .Â  Now using dmesg, and grepping for the “Manufacturer”, I can get the “FTDI”.Â  Now I grepÂ again for “FTDI” to get the device file name “ttyUSB0“.Â  This is all illustrated below:

item.title: Speech Synthesis on the Raspberry Pi
item.description:
Now that I can get sound out of my Raspberry Pi (RPi), the next logical step for me isÂ speech synthesis … Right? Â I foresee my RPi being used as a controller/gateway for other devices (e.g. RPi orÂ Arduino). Â In that capacity, I want the RPi to provide status via email, SMS, web updates, and so why not speech? Â Therefore, I’m looking for a good text-to-speech tool that will work nicely with my RPi.

The two dominate free speech synthesis tools forÂ LinuxÂ areÂ eSpeakÂ andÂ FestivalÂ (which has a light-weight version called Flite). Both tools appear very popular, well supported, andÂ produceÂ quality voices. Â I sensed that Festival is more feature reach and configurable, so I went with it.

To install Festival and Flite (which doesn’t require Festival to be installed), use the following command:

sudo apt-get install festival
<code>sudo apt-get install flite

Festival

To test out the installation, check out Festival’s man page, andÂ executeÂ the following:

echo "Why are you in front of the computer?" | festival --tts
date '+%A, %B %e, %Y' | festival --tts
festival --tts Gettysburg_Address.txt

Text, WAV, Mp3 Utilities

Festival also supplies a tool for converting text files into WAV files. Â This tool, called text2wave can be executes as follows:

text2wave -o HAL.wav HAL.txt
aplay HAL.wav

MP3 files can be 5 to 10 timesÂ smallerÂ than WAV files, so it might be nice toÂ convertÂ a WAV file to MP3. Â You can do this via a tool called lame.

lame HAL.wav HAL.mp3

Flite

Flite (festival-lite) is a small, fast run-time synthesis engine developed using Festival for small embedded machines. Taking aÂ famousÂ quote from HAL, the computer in the movie “2001: A Space Odyssey”

flite "Look Dave, I can see you're really upset about this. I honestly think you ought to sit down calmly, take a stress pill, and think things over."

Depending how the software was built for the package, you find that flite (and festival) has multiple voices. To find what voices where built in, use the command

flite -lv

To play a specific voice from the list, use the -voice parameter in the command

flite -voice kal "I'm now speaking kal's voice. By the way, please call me Dr. Hawking."

In my case, the defaultÂ voiceÂ appears to be “kal”, which sounds somewhat like Stephen Hawking. Â ”slt” appears to be a female version of the “kal” voice.

flite_time is a talking clock that can speak things like “The time is now, exactly two, in the afternoon.”

flite_time 14:00
flite_time `date +%H:%M`

Documentation

The documentation for Festival and Flite isn’t all that great but there does seem to be multiple sources. Â Here is what I found most useful:

    • Quick Start
    • More Complete

Update

Gary Hall of 878.org.uk made me aware of another method of getting speech out of the Raspberry Pi. His article Getting your Raspberry Pi to speak the weather forecast explains his very simple approach using Google Text to Speech service. See below

mplayer -ao alsa -really-quiet -noconsolecontrols "http://translate.google.com/translate_tts?tl=en&q=Look Dave, I can see you're really upset about this."

Some day, Google will rule the world!

item.title: Getting Audio Out Working on the Raspberry Pi
item.description:
I want to deliver sound from my Raspberry Pi’s (RPi) Audio Output 3.5mm jack. Â I’ll need to get audio drivers working on Audio Out, and to test it, I’ll need some sound files and players. Â I’m choosing the Advanced Linux Sound ArchitectureÂ (ALSA) driversÂ becauseÂ its widely supported and becauseÂ ALSAÂ not only provides audio but Â Musical Instrument Digital Interface (MIDI) functionality to Linux. Â  I’ll also be using the popular command line MP3 players, mpg321Â and the WAV player that comes with ALSA, aplay.

To get things going, I installed ALSA, a MP3 tools, and a WAV to MP3 conversion tool via the following commands:

sudo apt-get install alsa-utils
sudo apt-get install mpg321
sudo apt-get install lame

Enabling the Sound Module

Reboot the RP and when it comes back up, its time to load the Sound Drivers. Â This will be done viaÂ loadable kernel moduleÂ (LKM) which are object fileÂ Â that contains code to extend the LinuxÂ kernel. Â lsmodÂ is a command onÂ LinuxÂ systems which prints the contents of theÂ /proc/modulesÂ file. Â It shows whichÂ loadable kernel modulesÂ are currently loaded. Â In my case, lsmod gives me:

The snd-bcm2835 module appears to be already installed. RPi has aÂ BroadcomÂ Â BCM2835Â system on a chipÂ (SoC) which is a High Definition 1080p Embedded Multimedia Applications Processor. Â snd-bcm2835 is the sound driver. Â If Â lsmod doesn’t list the snd-bcn2835 module, then it can be installed via the following command:

sudo modprobe snd-bcm2835

Enabling Audio Output

By default, the RPi audio output is set to automatically select the digital HDMI interface ifÂ itsÂ being used, otherwise the analog audio output. You can force it to use a specific interface via the sound mixer controls. Â amixerÂ allows command-line control of the mixer for the ALSA driver.

You can force the RPi to use a specific interface using the commandÂ amixer cset numid=3 N where the N parameter means the following: 0=auto, 1=analog, 2=hdmi. Â Therefore, to force the Raspberry Pi to use the analog output:

amixer cset numid=3 1

Sound Check

With this done, you should be ready for a simple test. Â Plug a speaker into theÂ (RPi) Audio Output 3.5mm jack. Â I used a simple battery powered iHM60 iHome speaker. Â The jack will not deliver much power, so the speaker needs to be powered.

To test the RPi audio, you can play a WAV file (download this … excellent for user-error notification) with aplay, mpg321 for MP3 files, or use the speaker-test command if you don’t have a WAV/MP3 file.

aplay numnuts.wav
speaker-test -t sine -f 440 -c 2 -s 1
mpg321 "Mannish Boy.mp3"

More on the ALSA Sound Drivers and Utilities

While ALSA is a powerful tool, it documentation appears is very weak. Â Also, it appears that theÂ capabilitiesÂ of ALSA drivers and utilities are very Â dependent on the hardware used. Â The best sources of documentation that I found includeÂ Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) project homepage, Â archlinuxÂ Advanced Linux Sound Architecture,Â andÂ ALSA-sound-mini-HOWTO.

You can find useful information in the directory /proc, which is a “virtual” file system (meaning that it does not exist in real life, but merely is a mapping to various processes and tasks in your computer).

    • /proc/modules gives information about loadedÂ kernelÂ modules. Â The commandÂ lsmod | grep snd will list modulesÂ relevantÂ to the sound system.
    • You can check the existence of a soundcard by looking Â at cat /proc/asound/cards.
The amixer command can provide useful information (sometimes):
    • You can look at the mixer settings by typing amixer without any arguments. This command lists the mixer settings of the various parts of the soundcard. The output from amixer can greatly differ from card to card.Â UnfortunatelyÂ  you can’t find much documentation on how toÂ interpretÂ the out.
    • The RPi doesn’t have a “Master” control only “PCM”. Â So commands likeÂ amixer set Master... will not work. Â You must use amixer set PCM ...
    • You can mute /unmute the sound via these commands: amixer set PCM mute and amixer set PCM unmute
    • As of August 2012, there appears to be a known bugÂ in RPi ALSA driver that ignores volume settings at the start of playback and always plays at max volume. Â Therefore, commands like amixer set PCM 50% unmute will not set the volume to 50%, at least until this bug is fixed. Â Maybe this isn’t really a bug but a limitation of the hardware because there is a workaround for this …. see below.

Volume Control

The RPi built-in sound chips don’t have a “master volume” control, and as a result, you must control the volume via software. Â I guess the RPi views itself as a preamplifier (preamp) and volume controls would be supplied down stream. Â ALSA provides a software volume control using theÂ softvolÂ plugin.

The /etc/asound.confÂ file is a configuration files for ALSA driversÂ (system-wide). Â The main use of this configuration file is to add functionality. It allows you to create “virtual devices” that pre or post-process audio streams. Any properly written ALSA program can use these virtual devices as though they were normal devices. Â My RPi Â /etc/asound.confÂ file looks like this:

For most changes to /etc/asound.conf you will need to restart the sound server for the changes to take effect. You can do this via

sudo /etc/init.d/alsa-utils restart

I attempted to implement the software volume controls outline in a softvol how-to that I found, but I couldn’t get it to work. Â I did some additional digging, and I found a solution buried within a python script for a Adafruit project. Â The following works for controlling the volume (in this case, reducing the volume to 80% of maximum):

amixer cset numid=1 -- 80%

Note that you can use this command to change the volume while sound is being played an its effect takes placeÂ immediately. Â Also, I noticed that once the volume has been adjusted, its effect remains even after a reboot.

WAV and MP3 Conversion

The MP3 playerÂ mpg321Â can convert MP3 files to WAV files but the WAV player,Â aplay, can not do a conversion. Â To make a MP3 file from a WAV file, you’ll need the toolÂ lame.
    • To convert from WAV to MP3:Â lame input.wav output.mp3
    • To convert from MP3 to WAV: Â mpg321 -w output.wav input.mp3

Bottomeline

While you can get ALSA working on the Raspberry Pi, it appears only partly supported, maybe buggy, and poorly documented. Â If you just want to simply get sound out of the device (like I do), you’ll be fine. Â But if you have some desire to do some sound processing with ALSA, your likely to be very frustrated.

Epilogue

This specific post has gotten about 25% of all the viewings of my blog. I’m not sure why this is the case but I speculate that there are many people tying to make RPi into a Media Player and looking for answers to their technical problems.

At this point in time, others have done some additional postings and they are more instructive than my post. You should check out:

  • Sound configuration on Raspberry Pi with ALSA

item.title: Dropbox for the Raspberry Pi (sort of)
item.description:
I’m presently using Dropbox as a service for quick & easy movementÂ of files between multiple PCs I use. Â Its copy & paste operation is very intuitiveÂ on a Windows PC. I would like the same on the Raspberry Pi (RPi), particularly for moving files from my PC to the RPi. Â I wanted the same utility on my RPi, but at the same time, I want the Linux command line paradigm supported and not be force to run X Windows on the RPi.

I did someÂ searching and found things like Dropbox’s Linux distribution (which I wasn’t confident would work “out of the box” for the RPi’s ARM architecture, but source is provided), Â GoodSyncÂ or Owncloud (which wouldn’t access my existing Dropbox files but instead create an alternative), python or Â bash shell based up/down loaders (appears to behave like aÂ simplifiedÂ FTP tool), or theÂ Secure SHell File System (SSHFS) based approach (the PC’s Dropbox directory is mounted on the RPi).

While the Dropbox’s Linux distribution is likely the ultimate way to go, I didn’t want to commit myself to the effort it would potentially require. Â I settled on theÂ SSHFSÂ based approach. Â I’m running my RPi headless and access it via my PC using Cygwin/X and Secure Shell (ssh). Â With the SSHFS approach, I could make the DropboxÂ directory availableÂ for mounting at boot-up or mount it at will. Â I onlyÂ envisionÂ using the RPi-based Dropbox when I’m doing development and I will be doing that from my PC. Â So this SSHFS approach seems fine for the way that I operate.

The SSHFS approach means files will not really be replicated on the RPi, like Dropbox does. Â The files will reside within my PC’s Dropbox folder (and replicated on my other PCs via the Dropbox service) butÂ accessibleÂ by the RPi via the SSHFS file mount. Â This means I can’t have any applications I run on the RPi depend on files located in its Dropbox directory since it may not be always mounted. Â I’m OK with this limitation, and in fact is consistent with the ad-hoc purpose I have for the Dropbox directory.

Installation Required on the PC

For me, nothing needs to be done here. Â I already have Dropbox running on my PC, and via Cygwin/X, I have the foundations required for the host side of the SSHFS solution. Â If you need help with this,Â signup for Dropbox hereÂ and find out how I’m using Cygwin/X here.

Installation Required on the RPi

On the client side of the solution, you’ll need to installÂ SSHFS and FUSE.Â FUSE is the user-space filesystem framework and is the foundation on which SSHFS resides. FUSE allows user-space software, SSH in this case, to present a virtual file system interface to the user; something generally only done by the Linux kernel. Â SSHFS connects to the remote system and provide the look and feel of a regular file system interface for remote files. On the RPi, install SSHFS via the command:

sudo apt-get install sshfs

FUSE appear to be already installed on the RPi or maybe comes with SSHFS. Next you need to add required users to the FUSE usergroup. Â In my case, that is the user pi. Â You can see the existing groups pi is part of via the command groups pi. Â You can validate that the FUSE user group has been created by using the command cat /etc/group | grep fuse. Â To add pi to the FUSE userÂ group, use the command:

sudo gpasswd -a pi fuse

The fuse group lets you limit which users are allowed to use FUSE-based file systems, in my case the Dropbox. This is important because FUSE installs setuid programs, which always carry security implications.

Configuring the Dropbox File System

Now its time to make your Dropbox directory on the RPi, and mount it to the PC’s instance of Dropbox. On the RPi, use this command to create the Dropbox:

mkdir ~/Dropbox

The next thing to do is to make sure that you can connect to the PC via ssh. Â When I installed Cygwin, my focus was on using it as an X Server and making sshÂ connectionsÂ from the PC to RPi. Â I neverÂ triedÂ the inverse (connect from the RPi to the PC) and that is what SSHFS is effectively doing. Â So check for two things:

    • Is the ssh server running on the PC? Â You can check for its status via the commandÂ cygrunsrv -Q sshd. In my case it was running, so its fine.
    • Is the port used by the ssh server on the PC open? You’ll need to open SSH port 22 for ssh services to work. Â You can check its status by attempting to use it. Â In my case, this wasÂ ssh Jeff@HomePC.home. Â If this command appears to hang or time out (as it did for me), the port is likely blocked. Â You’ll need to go to your Windows Firewall and open port 22.
There is another Cygwin sublimityÂ that has to be taken into consideration. Â When using the Cygwin, Windows drive letters are mapped to a special directory. Â In my case, the Dropbox directory appears to Cygwin to have the following path: /cygdrive/c/Users/Jeff/Dropbox.

With this all addressed, reboot the RPi, and then you can now fire up you RPi Dropbox via:

sshfs Jeff@HomePC.home:/cygdrive/c/Users/Jeff/Dropbox ~/Dropbox

After you supply the PC’s password, you should now be able to access the Dropbox directory on the PC. Â If you wish, you can remove the file system connection to the PC via the command:

fusermount -u ~/Dropbox

This connection will stay established as long as you don’t do the fusermount -u or reboot the RPi. Â If you wish to mount the file system upon boot-up, andÂ avoidÂ executing the sshfs when youÂ log-in, you can follow theÂ procedureÂ outline in the article that initially inspired me:Â Dropbox on Raspberry Pi via SSHFS

Something to Keep in Mind

While for the most part, moving between Windows/DOS and the Linux file systemsÂ isn’t a problem, there is one thing to remember.Â Windows-based text editors put one set of special characters at the end of lines (i.e. carriage return and line break = ‘\r\n’), while Unix/Linux puts other characters (i.e. line break = ‘\n’). Â This odd anomaly is normally harmless, but some applications on a Linux cannot understand these characters and can cause Linux to not respond correctly.

The best example of LinuxÂ behaving badly (and the only one I know) is the execution of âshebangâ or the â#!…â at the top of a bash, python, perl, etc. script.Â  If you edit these files in DOS, then move them to Linux, shebang will stop working.Â  Editing them under DOS is the origin of the problem, since a DOS based text editor will inject the extra carriage return character at the end of the text line.

To fix this problem, you can quickly convert an ASCII text file from DOS format (carriage return and line break) to the Unix format (line break), you can use the tool dos2unix.Â  Run this utility on the effected file and shebang should work once again.

Epilogue

At itsÂ foundation, SSHÂ functions as a protocol for authenticating and encrypting remote shell sessions. Â SSH can be thought of asÂ much more than just a secure shell. Â Using SSH’s foundation, SSHFS creates a new capability. Â To learn more, check out the linkÂ SSH: More than secure shell.

Key sources I consulted to write this include:

    • SSHFS: Super Easy File Access over SSH
    • Dropbox on Raspberry Pi via SSHFS
    • Mount a remote file system through ssh Using sshfs

item.title: SendEmail as a Messaging Tool for the Raspberry Pi
item.description:
In the projects IÂ envisionÂ for the future, I’ll be using my Raspberry Pi (RPi) as a gateway/server/controller for several other devices. Â There is likely to be a need to generate status reports/messages and mail them out. It could be as simple as a notification that the deck lights have been turned-on. I don’t need a fullÂ fledged mail client on the RPi toÂ receiveÂ mail or manage a mailbox, just a command line utility to send email. Â Also, I would like to send short text messages via (SMS) to my cell phone. Â Linux does have a nice solution for this.

You do need an established email account with some email provider.Â I want to keep my personal email and my RPi’s emailÂ separateÂ  so I setup aÂ specialÂ email account on gmail. Â This will be used only by myÂ RaspberryÂ Pi’s (or other intelligent devices). There exist some open SMTP relay mail servers (mailÂ serversÂ that will not require a login nor a password) but many open mail relays have become unpopular and closed due to their exploitation by spammers and worms.

SendEmail

SendEmail is a lightweight,Â completelyÂ command line based, SMTP email agent. It isÂ writtenÂ in Perl and designed to be used on the command line, in bash scripts, Perl programs, within web sites, etc.

I installed SendEmail on my RPi via this command:

sudo apt-get install sendemail

Testing sendEmail

When I ran sendEmail the first time, itÂ complainedÂ about some missing libraries. Â I installed the missing libraries and this cleared the error. Â Clearly, the sendEmail package needs some work since this dependency should have been taken care of by apt-get.

I ran it again using this command:

sendEmail -f pi@RedRPi -t <my_user_name>@verzion.net -u "Test Email from RedRPi" -m "My test message." -s smtp.gmail.com:587Â Â -o tls=yes -xu <my_user_name> -xp <my_password>

With this, sendEmail threw an error message:

invalid SSL_version specified at /usr/share/perl5/IO/Socket/SSL.pm line 332

I did a web search and found that this is a reported bug within sendEmail (bummer), but I also found a simple patch for the problem (lucky break). Â I applied the fix, executed the command again, and succeeded in sending the email.

One of the key parameter used here is the SMTPÂ mail relayÂ specified inÂ Â ”-s smtp.gmail.com:587“. Â In this case, Gmail uses port 587 for relay email. Â TheÂ defaultÂ port to use is 25 but not all emailÂ serversÂ use this port.

Another key parameter is “-o tls=yes“. This specifies that theÂ Transport Layer Security (TLS)Â protocolÂ will be used toÂ provide communicationÂ securityÂ over theÂ Internet. Â This is important since your including a plain-text password in the command.

SMS Messaging

Another messaging mechanism that I plan to use is Short Message Service (SMS). Â To do this, you can use a SMS gateway which will transform an email into an SMS message. Â The down side is that there isn’t a single gateway but one for each of the cellularÂ carries.

Here is an example for AT&T cell phones:

sendEmail -f pi@RedRPi -t <cell_phone_number>@txt.att.net -u "Test Email from RedRPi" -m "My test message." -s smtp.gmail.com:587Â Â -o tls=yes -xu <my_user_name> -xp <my_password>

item.title: WiFi (with WEP Security) on Raspberry Pi
item.description:
The Raspberry Pi Linux distribution I’m using is Adafruit’s Occidentalis. Â It supports WiFi out of the box and appears easy to configure. Â But as noted by Adafruit, adding peripherals to the RPi may increase the loading on the power supply to your board and this, in turn, may affect the voltage presented to the RPi.

This is clearly the case, even for the tiny Â OURlinkÂ WiFi (802.11b/g/n) USB Adapter (uses theÂ RTl8192cu chipÂ which is supported by Debian Linux) I purchased from Adafruit. Â When I plugged it into the RPi, it became unstable and crashed. Â AdafruitÂ advisesÂ that you can over come this by attach the RPi’s USB port to a powered hub. Â (Note that all USB hubsÂ aren’tÂ powered or powered sufficient, andÂ therefore, not all are Â recommended. Â I used a Dynex 4 Port Hub with a 5V 2.1A power adapter and all seem fine.) Â If you find using a using a USB hub completely unacceptable, you could make some RPi board modificationsÂ to the polyfuses, but this isn’t the “official/supported” approach for this power problem …. but first …. see theÂ Epilogue below.

My First Attempt (Unsuccessful)

Once I got the RPi USB port properly powered, I followed the Adafruit’s instructions. Â I updated the/etc/network/interfacesÂ file with the following:

########## DID NOT WORK FOR ME ##########

# The loopback network interface
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

# The primary (wired) network interface
iface eth0 inet dhcp

# The wifi (wireless) network interface
auto wlan0
allow-hotplug wlan0
iface wlan0 inet dhcp
      wpa-ssid YOUR_SSID
      wpa-psk YOUR_WEP_KEY

I ranÂ Â ifconfig -a and got the following:

This tells me that Linux sees the WiFi device and assigned it device name wlan0. It also says there isn’t an IP address assigned and no data is moving. Â Appears that network interface wlan0 isn’t running so IÂ triedÂ bring it up withÂ sudo ifup wlan0 and I got the following:

No IP assigned … now what?

This Worked … But

After the typical thrashing about, it came to me that I’m not using WAP security (which is implied by the/etc/network/interfacesÂ file content) but I’m using WEP. Â I did some web searching and found a site that claimed toÂ addressÂ Debian WiFi WEP configuration. Â This provided me the needed commandÂ syntaxÂ for the solution. Â Â I updated the/etc/network/interfacesÂ file with the following:

# The loopback network interface
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

# The primary (wired) network interface
iface eth0 inet dhcp

# The wifi (wireless) network interface
auto wlan0
allow-hotplug wlan0
iface wlan0 inet dhcp
       wireless-essid YOUR_SSID
       wireless-key YOUR_WEP_KEY

I then ran sudo ifup wlan0 to start the wireless networking (Note: you can use sudo ifdown wlan0 to turn-off the wireless network). Â This time DHCPÂ discovery appeared toÂ work. Â I then ran ifconfig -a giving me the displayÂ belowÂ with anÂ assignedÂ wireless IP.

The wireless device now has an IP address and data seems to be flowing. Â In an effort to furtherÂ convinceÂ myself that the WiFi was working, I disconnected the wired ethernetÂ connection and attempted to re-login in viaÂ ssh -X pi@RedRPi.local, over the wireless interface. This failed, giving the message:

ssh: Could not resolve hostname RedRPi.local: hostname nor servname provided, or not known

Working For Sure

I suspected (after more thrashing about) it was Ssh orÂ Avahi/BonjourÂ or both that was getting in the way. Â So I did the following:

    1. I cleaned out the ~/.ssh/known_hostsÂ file on the PC from which I’m accessing the RPi (I’m using Cygwin with Openssh). With the entries in the fileÂ removedÂ  ssh keys would need to be recreated on next login.
    2. I then logged into the RPiÂ in viaÂ ssh -X pi@RedRPi.local. The login created an entryÂ theÂ ~/.ssh/known_hostsÂ file on the PC.
    3. Using vi, I edited the Â ~/.ssh/known_hostsÂ file. Â I duplicated the oneÂ existingÂ record but changed the Â IP address to the wireless address.
    4. I restarted the openssh on the PC. Â (I terminated all the Cygwin window and restarted them. Â I could get anything else to work short of a PC reboot).
    5. I then logged in using ssh -X pi@192.168.1.7. Now I’m wireless!!

MyÂ ~/.ssh/known_hostsÂ file looks like this:

Epilogue

I have found that ifÂ  I don’t use a USB Â powered hub and I plug in theÂ OURlinkÂ WiFi (802.11b/g/n) USB Adapter while the RPi is up and running, the RPi will crash. Â The good news is that, once the RPi reboots, it runs fine without the powered hub.

So, go ahead and use the WiFi USB Adapter, without the powered hub, but make sure the adapter isÂ pluggedÂ in when you boot up …. problem solved!

item.title: Controlling and Viewing the Raspberry Pi GPIO via PC Browser
item.description:
This idea of controlling my Raspberry Pi (RPi), and the things its networked with, via an internet browser is at the heart of what I would like to do with theÂ assortmentÂ ofÂ ArduinoÂ and Xbee devices I’m assembling. Â To explore how best to do this, I’m considering usingÂ WebIOPi, which is a web application used to control your RPiâs GPIO. Â IÂ believeÂ it could be useful as a test tool, but more importantly, I suspect that I could learn how to engineer myÂ applicationÂ byÂ studyingÂ its design.

Install WebIOPi

When installing WebIOPi on my RPi, I followed theÂ installation instructions for the Apache version. Â I choose this version since Â I’ll be using the Apache web server for other features as my project evolves. Note that there is a small error on the instructions if you use aÂ symbolicÂ link to the webiopi directory. Â Create this link using

sudo ln -s /home/pi/webiopi /var/www/webiopi

Immediately afterÂ installation,Â  you can test to see if you canÂ renderÂ a web page. Â Assuming that yourÂ Â Raspberry Pi is connected to your network Â and its named raspberrypi, you can open a browser toÂ http://raspberrypi/webiopi/Â with your network PC. Â It might work but your likely to get a error, something like “…Could not reliably determine the serverâs fully qualified domain name…” and the solution is to give your web server a name.

To do this,Â Â create this Apache config file:

sudo vi /etc/apache2/conf.d/fqdn

Enter ServerName raspberrypi into this fileÂ and restart Apache using

sudo /etc/init.d/apache2 restart

Installing GPIO Utilities

While checking on the status of of the Python based GPIO package on the RPI using the command dpkg -l | grep gpio, I concluded that the Â OccidentalisÂ distribution I’m using doesn’t have any Python libraries for GPIO.

Picking up some tips fromÂ Raspberry Pi E-mail Notifier Using LEDs. Â I determined that I need to install several python packages first. Â I did this via

sudo apt-get install python
sudo apt-get install python-dev
sudo apt-get install python-pip

With this done, now its time to install the required PythonÂ librariesÂ but first,Â update the Python distribution by running

sudo easy_install -U distribute

Finally you can install the Raspberry Pi GPIO (General Purpose Input/Ouput) library:

sudo pip installÂ RPi.GPIO

What did I find

WebIOPi Â supports binary GPIOs, in both input and output. Â That is, you can set a GPIO output pin high/low via aÂ browserÂ pick. Â Also, you can see the state of a GPIO pin. item.title: Establishing an X Window System Environment for my PC and Raspberry Pi
item.description:
As stated in an earlier post, I plan to run my Raspberry Pi (RPi) as an attached device to my homes LAN and use my MS Windows PC to access the RPi. Â The RPiÂ will use my PC for display output and key board / mouse as input. Â With the X Window System on the RPi, I can transmit an entire RPi desktop if I wish (using LXDE and it would look and feel much like VNC).Â  I find this cumbersomeÂ since now your dealing with two desktop environments: MS Windows desktop and Â X Window System based desktop all one display.

There is an alternative way. One of the cool things about the X architecture is thatÂ it can use MS Windows as your window manager (at least with the tools like Cygwin/X, Xming, and MI/X) but the application within the window frame can be the RPiÂ based X Window System application.Â  Now you have a single desktop (MS Windows) but your running RPiÂ application within a MS Windows window.Â  And with this configuration, you can run both LinuxÂ programs within a standard terminalÂ windowÂ and graphicÂ Â X Window System applications in another window.

ForÂ me this is clearly the way to go.Â  It will allow me to hop on my PC, and with a double-clickÂ on a desktop icon, get me to a password promptÂ on the RPi.Â  Enter the password, and I can immediatelyÂ run both command lineÂ and X graphics application on the RPi, along sideÂ MS Windows applications, all concurrently on a single desktop.

How I did this, along with some background information, is provide below.

X Window System

The X Window System (commonly referred to as X Windows or just X or X11) is a software system and network protocol that provides a basis for graphical user interfaces (GUIs) and rich input device capability for networked computers. X uses a client/server model, but appears backwards when you first learn of X. Â In X, it’s the server that runs on the local machine (the PC), providing its services to the display based on requests from client programs that may be running remotely (the RPi). Within aÂ X Window System, a client can also run locally. The server also manages the input devices (your keyboard and mouse), and it manages the display of colors and fonts on the screen, all based on requests from a client.

One of the most significant features of X is that it was specifically designed to work across a network. The client and the server communicate via the X Protocol, a network protocol that can run locally or across a network. Regardless of whether a client program is local or remote, it communicates with the server through the X Protocol.

X Window SystemÂ Components

A X Window SystemÂ consistÂ of several components which work together. Â They are:
    • X Server - manages theÂ display, based on requests from the window manager.
    • Window Manager - isÂ an application that is itself an X client, with responsibility for managing the appearance and placement of the windows on the screen. Â Â The window manager takes care of the appearance and placement of the windows; it doesn’t determine what goes on inside.
    • Windows - are the X clients,Â typicallyÂ providing user functionality. Â Windows are fully in control of the application but their placement,Â geometryÂ  etc. are controlled by the window manager.
    • Display ManagerÂ - runs as a program that allows the starting of aÂ sessionÂ on an XÂ serverÂ from the same local or remote computerÂ A display managerÂ presents the user with aÂ login screenÂ which prompts for aÂ usernameÂ andÂ password. A session starts when the user successfully enters a valid combination of username and password.
        • When the display manager runs on the user’s computer, it starts the X server before presenting the user the login screen, optionally repeating when the user logs out.
        • When the display manager runs on a remote computer, it acts like aÂ telnetÂ server, requesting username and password and starting a remote session.
    • Â Desktop Environment -Â go further than a window manager in providing an integrated graphical environment where all applications and windows have a common look and feel. The desktop environments also include session management, for saving and restoring your work sessions.
In theÂ spiritÂ ofÂ user-friendliness and security, the desktop and display manager hides much of the X Window System and its’Â subtleties. Â If you want to really explore X (and light its load on the RPi), it’s helpful to run with just a window manager for a while (even if you plan to go back to the desktop). Â That is what I plan to do.

Cygwin’s X Server and Window Manager

Before you can run a XÂ client, you need to start the X server. Â You can run the X server in two ways: it willÂ automaticallyÂ start if your Linux is configured with a X Display Manager (XDM), and if not, at the Linux command line you can start X manually. Â It is the latter that I want to do on my PC / RPiÂ combination (and the way my RPiÂ distributionÂ OccidentalisÂ is pre-configured). Â  Also, in myÂ configuration, I’ll be using the CygwinÂ Â X server on the PC, and no server will be running on the RPi, only X clients.

Now there are some important capabilities within the CygwinÂ X server. Â Cygwin/X can work with its window managersÂ  in several different ways.

    • Internal window managerÂ - The internal window manager creates a MS Windows window for each top-level X window. Â This window manage is “internal” to the Cygwin X server.
    • External local window managersÂ - Â These local window managers must be installed on CygwinÂ and runs on the PCÂ (e.g.Â twm,Â mwm,Â fvwm2,Â openbox,Â aewm++,Â WindowMaker).
    • Remote window managersÂ - This would be a situation where the window manager is on the RPiÂ and would connect via aÂ remote sessions using XDMCP (X Display Manager Control Protocol).
I plan to keep things simple and use the CygwinÂ internalÂ window manage.

XWinÂ is the X Server for the X Window System on the Cygwin environment running on Microsoft Windows.Â It can operate in three different modes:

    • Single Window -Â This is the default mode. Each X screen appears as a single MSÂ WindowsÂ window and all X windows are contained within this window. (In X terminology, the MSÂ WindowsÂ window contains the root window for the screen.)
    • Multi-Window -Â In this modeÂ XWinÂ uses its own integrated window manager in order to handle the top-level X windows, in such a way that they appear as normalÂ MSÂ WindowsÂ windows.
    • Rootless -Â In this mode the X server works in a window containing the whole screen but this root window (traditionally covered with an X hatch pattern) is hidden from view, so only top-level X windows are seen.
To get a better idea on what the different modes can provide you from a user experience perspective, check out someÂ Cygwin/X screen shots. Â Â Again, my objectives are toÂ keep things simple and clean, so I will be using the multi-window mode.

Configuring Cygwin/X

To operate Cygwin/X in multi-window mode you use the command startxwin (You use startx for window mode.Â  startxwin is a specialized version of startxÂ with a few differences appropriate to running in multi-window mode, rather than windowed mode). Â The startxwin program has a resource file called .startxwinrc.Â  You can create a ~/.startxwinrcÂ script to start client programs, such as minttyÂ or xterm. An example .startxwinrc fileÂ is:

mintty --position 150,150 --size 80,50
minttyÂ --position 600,500 --size 80,25 --exec ssh -X pi@raspberrypi.local

This will open up two xterm windows for your in the left hand corner of the screen and a thrid xterm window in the center of the screen. Â This third screen is automaticallyÂ loggingÂ in to the RPi as user pi and will wait four you to enter the password.

Also make sure that you export your DISPLAY for the X server on your PC. Â You can do this by placing theÂ followingÂ in your .bashrc file:

# environment variables required by X Window System
export DISPLAY=:0.0

Configuring RPi

Not much needs to be done to the RPi to prepare for the X applications. Â You may wish to launch some X Window System applicationÂ uponÂ loggingÂ in. Â You can do this by adding the X applications to your .bash_profile. Â For example, add the following line to launch the LXDE file manager:

# execute X Window System programs
pcmanfm &

Starting and Stopping the Cygwin X Server

The environments are now set. Â Time to start the X Server. TheÂ easiestÂ way for starting Cygwin/XÂ isÂ using the “XWinÂ Server” shortcut under “Cygwin-X” on the Start Menu or on the MS Windows desktop. You could also type startxwinÂ on the Cygwin command line.

As to stopping the X Server, for the window mode I’m working in (multi-window), stopping Cygwin/X can be done byÂ Â Selecting the “Exit…” option from the notification area icon menu.

How Does It Look

So given the configuration discussed above, your get a nice clean display with MS Windows, Cygwin, RPi command line, and RPi X Window application running in a single windows management environment. Â Picture provided below:

You thought the Raspberry Pi was a simple little hardwareÂ hackers computer …. but its running like a big dog now!

References

Much of what is provided here was lifted from theÂ followingÂ sources:
    • What Is the X Window System
    • How Linux X Works
    • Using Cygwin/X
    • Cygwin/X Userâs Guide
    • The X Window System

item.title: Setting up Git for Arduino and Raspberry Pi Development
item.description:
For my future projects, I plan to do a combination of Arduino and RPi development. Â The development of the Arduino code will be on my MS Windows PC and the RPi solution will be developedÂ naivelyÂ within the RPi LinuxÂ environmentÂ  Â Given this distributedÂ environment (and my ability toÂ bungleÂ things), I canÂ foreseeÂ  potential problems maintain good source code control. Â To deal with this, theÂ combinationÂ of git andÂ gethubÂ seems the right way to proceed …. after all it has worked for the distributedÂ Linux development community.

Git on MS Windows

The first thing I did was to set up git within my MS Windows PC. Â Given thatÂ I installed CygwinÂ when setting up the RPi, that is where I returned to install git. Â Therefore, I plan to use git within the CygwinÂ environmentÂ on my PC and not within MS Windows per say. Â This could be done, but my approachÂ allowsÂ me to learn git commands once since, Cygwin is a Linux-likeÂ environment, everything should look and operate the same.

To accomplish this I follow the instructions outline inÂ Installing Git on Cygwin. Â These instructions are veryÂ straightÂ forward. Â TheÂ challenge was in initializing git for my first project, at least it was aÂ challengeÂ for me since git is new tool for me and Cygwin didn’t always cooperate. Â I had to address this the old fashion way …. read the documentation and trouble logs (vs. doing a web search for someones web post with instructions). Â All the important secretsÂ of git can be found widely dispersed andÂ buriedÂ deep withing these web sites:Â GitÂ DocumentationÂ andÂ Git Reference. Â Source information from trouble logs will be listed below.

So how did I do it? Â It’s easy once youÂ successivelyÂ done it once. Â First let me state the context; for the exercise I’m doing, I’mÂ attemptingÂ to place myÂ .bashrc, .profile, .vimrc, and a few other configuration files under gits control. Â The basicÂ sequenceÂ of operation is toÂ initializeÂ the gitÂ environment, configure some parameters, and then add the files. Â It goes like this (I’ll let you research the git documentation, just like I did, to understand the command. Â TrustÂ me, this is good for you!): 

git init
git config --global user.name "jeffskinnerbox"
git config --global user.email jeff.irland@verizon.net
git config --global core.editor vim
git config --global merge.tool vimdiff
git add .bashrc .profile .vimrc .bash_profile .minttyrc .inputrcÂ .gitconfig .gitignore

To see what you got, use the git status command. Â This will tell you the files got staged but not committed. The commit will come later. Â First we need to set up our communal repository within github.

Setting Up GitHub

You may be asking, What Exactly Is GitHubÂ Anyway? Â Well, in a few words, githubÂ is aÂ web-based hosting serviceÂ for software development projects that use git. The next step is to go toÂ github, set up your free login, and then set up a repository. Â In my case, I set up a github repository calledÂ Cygwin-Configuration-Files to store myÂ configurationÂ files established earlier under gitÂ control. Â It will be empty at this point, andÂ that’sÂ all for now, loading it with files comes later.

I didn’t say much about how to set up github, but trust me, it is as simple as outlined above. Â It’s via git that all the real work takes place. Â GitHub is all about giving you an off-site, web-access-able, complete versionÂ controlledÂ historicalÂ record of your code that can be shared with others.

Back to Git within Cygwin

Now that we have established github andÂ initialized, configured, and added files to the CygwinÂ environmentÂ  we can associated the PC and github environments. Â It wasn’t clear to me, from the git documentation, how to best do this association. Â Using Â git clone isn’tÂ intuitiveÂ to me, but it seems to work. Â This is how I did it:

git cloneÂ https://github.com/jeffskinnerbox/Cygwin-Configuration-Files.git

Warning … You may, as I did, get the following error:

Cloning into 'Cygwin-Configuration-Files'...
error: error setting certificate verify locations:
CAfile: /usr/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt
CApath: none while accessing https://github.com/jeffskinnerbox/Cygwin-Configuration-Files.git/info/refs
fatal: HTTP request failed

If you get the above error,Â the problem is that Cygwin hasn’t installed the ca-certificates package. Â Run the Cygwin installer again, and add that package; after that git clone should start working.

The next step is to commit your files to the git localÂ repositoryÂ within the PC under Cygwin. Â To do this, execute the following command:

git commit

You will be put into vim to provide a comment that will be posted with the git version. Â Why vim? Â Because you executed the commandÂ git config --global core.editor vimÂ  earlier. Â If you don’t want to use vim for adding comments under git, supply another editor when you do the configuration step.

The next step, which strictly isn’t required but a nice to have, is to associate aÂ descriptiveÂ identifier with the github repository. Â TheÂ descriptorÂ I used is “Cygwin-Configuration-Files”. Â The command I used is:

git remote add Cygwin-Configuration-Files https://github.com/jeffskinnerbox/Cygwin-Configuration-Files.git

The final step is to push your local files to the githubÂ repository,

git push Cygwin-Configuration-Files

WarningÂ … It was during the git push that I ran into another problem, but it could happen nearly any time. Â I discovered that sometimes, after multiple Cygwin updating or installing packages, you’ll start to get strange errors related to “fork()” or .dll loading. After some research, I discoved these errors are usually solved by rebasing your packages. Â While rebasing, which is executed using the Cygwin rebaseall command, is is a bit of aÂ mystery, it doesÂ appearÂ to work

Rebasing Cygwin

Before you can run the rebaseallÂ command,Â you’ll need to make sure no Cygwin-based services are running. Â  To do this, you need to run two cygwin command, cygrunsrc and rebaseall, Â under the ash command in MS Windows command prompt, not in a Cygwin Terminal window. Â  The sequence of activity is as follows:
    1. Exit the Cygwin Terminal
    2. Run as administrator the MS Windows Command Prompt window
    3. Execute ash via \cygwin\bin\ash.exe
    4. Now under ash, see if any Cygwin processes are running via /usr/bin/cygrunsrc -L
    5. Stop any of the Â running processes via /usr/bin/cygrunsrc --stop <process's>
    6. Now do the rebase via /usr/bin/rebaseall
For an example the steps above performedÂ within the Command Prompt under ash, see below:

Git on the Raspberry Pi

Admittedly, getting git setup under MS Windows / Cygwin isn’t a walk in the park. Â It appears to work fine once set up, but the setup process can be painful.

Git under the Raspberry Pi’s Linux installs flawlessly, as you would expect, given git origins. Â First you Â install git viaÂ sudo apt-get install git. Â Then, just as was done above, do theÂ initializationÂ of the gitÂ environment, configure some parameters, Â add the files, setup the github, clone, and push.

In my case, I setup aÂ separateÂ Â a githubÂ repositoryÂ called RPI-Configuration-FilesÂ to store my RPi configurationÂ files. Â I could have used the same repository as was setup for the PCÂ environmentÂ but that didn’t make sense for my present needs.

Conclusion

So that’s it! Â Its a long post for what is really a simple to use tool, but setting it up the first time could be aÂ challenge.

Once I got the RPi up and runningÂ headlessÂ on my local network, its time to build the software foundation that I’ll need to make it an effective development environment. Â These are the packages that I loaded to get myself up and running.

Do Your House Cleaning First

I’m loading software via the Linux apt-get utility and you need to make sure its database is up to date. First thing to do is to update apt-get’s local database with server’sÂ pkglist’s files. Â ThenÂ checks for outdated packages in the system and automatically upgrades them. Â Execute the following commands:

sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get upgrade

Search for Package or Package Description

Some times you don’t know package name but aware of some keywords to search the package. Â To search for packages, use the following:

apt-cache search "text-to-search" apt-cache search "text-to-search" | grep "more-search-text"

Synaptic

Synaptic is a graphical package management program for Linux software. It provides the same features as the apt-get command line utility with a X Windows GUI front-end. Â While I will not be using X Windows at this moment, in the future I will and synaptic is a very nice alternative to apt-get when in in X Windows.

sudo apt-get install synaptic

Vim

Vim is a highly configurable text editor andÂ widelyÂ available for many different platforms. Â Emacs also has a large following, but I think everyone needs to be prepared to useÂ vim if your serious about Linux. Â The RPi Linux distribution appears to have vi loaded but vim is aÂ superiorÂ tool.

sudo apt-get install vim sudo apt-get install vim-gtk

PyRoom

PyRoom is aÂ a fullscreen editor without buttons, widgets, formatting options, menus and with only the minimum of required dialog windows, it doesn’t have any distractions and lets you focus on writing and only writing. Â It is the polar opposite of Vim, and as such, is a good editor for the novice orÂ casualÂ user, but requires X Windows and Python.

sudo apt-get install pyroom

Git

Given that I plan to hack some to-be-determined applications using the RPi, I should consider establish some tools forÂ Â source code management. The last time I did serious software development in Linux (really Unix), I was using Source Code Control System (SCCS). The tools are much improved now and git is hands down the way to go.

sudo apt-get install git

Chromium

We all have aÂ favoriteÂ browser and I choose chromium for my RPi. Â Chromium serves as a base for Google Chrome, which is ChromiumÂ re-brandedÂ (name and logo) with very few additions.

sudo apt-get install chromium

  • SRAM (Static Random Access Memory) is where the sketch creates and manipulates variables when it runs.

item.title: Raspberry Pi has Arrived
item.description:
On Friday, September 7th, my Raspberry Pi arrived! Â A $35Â hackableÂ Linux box … not a bad deal! Â I got it fromÂ Newark/element14, one of the few place where you can order a Raspberry Pi and not wait for many weeks.

IÂ immediatelyÂ proceededÂ to set it up, and after over coming the typical barriers (e.g. my PC’s SD Card reader wouldn’tÂ cooperate), things came together very nicely. Â Here is how I did it.

What Raspberry Pi software distribution should I use?

Given that my objectives are to do some hardware hackingÂ usingÂ the Pi, I quickly concluded that the distribution being offered by Adafruit was for me. Adafruit offers a distribution called Occidentalis. Â Unlike the typical Raspberry Pi software distributions, it comes equipped with Â access to SPI, I2C, one wire, and WiFi preconfigured. It also has some things to make overall use easier, such as sshd onÂ start-upÂ  and Bonjour (so you can simply do ssh pi@raspberrypi.local from my PC when I place the Pi on my local network). Â And it appears that Adafruit will continue to support and enhance the software as things evolve with the Pi.

I followed the instructionsÂ given by Adafruit and had no problems. Â IÂ suggestÂ when you do the first boot up, hook up the Pi with a monitor and keyboard to do the initial configuration. Â Once that isÂ accomplished, you can leverage the installedÂ Avahi (zeroconf or zero configuration networking)Â daemon (i.e.Â Bonjour-likeÂ service), as I do below.

How can I access the Raspberry Pi via my PC through my local network?

I have seen this called “running headless”. Â For me, this is the way to go. Â The last thing I need is another monitor and keyboard to peck at. Â Key to this will be getting a terminal emulator and a X terminal running on my PC. I choose Cygwin/X to get this job done. Cygwin/X comes with all theÂ CygwinÂ utilities, but for me, that is a good thing.

On to your PC, download Cygwin/X and use the set-up procedures listed at theÂ Setting Up Cygwin/XÂ page. Â During the “Select Packages” step (step 15), also make sure to include theÂ opensshÂ package.

How do you get shh working on the PC?

This proves to be very easy despite the potential complexities. Follow the procedures in “How To Get SSH Command-Line Access to Windows 7 Using Cygwin“.

How do you connect from the PC to the Raspberry Pi?

Fire up Cygwin Terminal on your PC, and at the prompt, enter

ssh pi@raspberrypi.local

You’ll then be asked for the password for the pi login, enter it, and your should be in the Raspberry Pi via terminal emulation. Note that this is all being done without the assistance of a X Server on the PC. Â Your not running in X Windows … that comes next (Make sure to exit the Pi and return back to the Cygwin Terminal for the next step).

How do you run X Windows on theÂ RaspberryÂ Pi and use the PC as your X Terminal?

If you want to run X Windows on the Raspberry Pi with your PC being the X Server display, you need to provide a Display Name and the start the X Server. Â This is done within Â following command in the Cygwin Terminal:

export DISPLAY=:0.0
startxwin &

Now you should start an XÂ Terminal (Cygwin/X has a light weight version called mintty). Â So type in the following into the Cygwin Terminal.

mintty &

Within the mintty window, log into the Raspberry PI:

ssh -Y pi@raspberrypi.local

An once in the Raspberry Pi, startup the LXDE Desktop Client using the command:

startlxde

You should now be in the Pi running X Windows! Â No need for an extra keyboard, mouse, or monitor!

Some fine tuning will be necessary so you don’t have to do the export DISPLAY=:0.0 every time you login and other things, but that is all that what is needed to get going.
